The 38-bed facility wrote on social medi", "spa": "Washington, 6 may (EFE).- Cerca de 70 millones de estadounidenses experimentar\u00e1n tormentas, tornados y granizadas en las Planicies y el valle del r\u00edo Ohio, en la regi\u00f3n central del pa\u00eds, seg\u00fan avis\u00f3 este lunes el Centro de Pron\u00f3sticos de Tormenta (SPC, en ingl\u00e9s).\n\n\"Es probable que haya m\u00faltiples tornados fuertes y de largo surco, granizo y fuertes vientos da\u00f1inos este lunes\", indic\u00f3 en un mensaje el SPC, que avis\u00f3 que estas condiciones para estos fen\u00f3menos podr\u00edan extenderse hasta "}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 72}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 80}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 255, "spa": 51}, "sentiment": -0.2470588235294118}
{"uri": "8114708491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "02:23:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T02:23:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T02:22:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9529411792755127, "url": "https://ksltv.com/642207/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-of-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms/", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla. (AP) -- Millions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAs early evening approached, ominous wall clouds were forming in Oklahoma, and apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.", "source": {"uri": "ksltv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSLTV.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346997867", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "22:22:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T22:22:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:50:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9411764740943909, "url": "https://phl17.com/nmw/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-of-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms/", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "(AP) - Millions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.", "source": {"uri": "phl17.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "phl17"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-347007190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "22:39:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T22:39:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T22:16:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9372549057006836, "url": "https://www.oneindia.com/international/severe-weather-threatens-millions-in-oklahoma-kansas-011-3818245.html", "title": "Millions in Oklahoma, Kansas Brace for Severe Tornadoes and Storms", "body": "Millions in Oklahoma, Kansas Brace for Severe Tornadoes and Storms\n\nMillions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas. Much of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.The National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes. In all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Services Storm Prediction Center said. Schools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and cancelled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.Oklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday. Monte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbours know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls. Tucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.Bill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said. The last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.The risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said. \"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said. Cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.The number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said. The expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph 49.71 kph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\" The high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph 46.60 kph have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.The winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office. Colorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.The dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said. \"This is not going to be an atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"The entire week is looking stormy across the US. The eastern US and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.Meanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues. Bunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan. \"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.", "source": {"uri": "oneindia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oneindia"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sathish_raman@oneindia.com", "name": {"uri": "2024-05-346967567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:31:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:31:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2929773-severe-weather-threat-tornadoes-thunderstorms-pose-risk-to-millions-in-oklahoma-and-southern-kansas", "title": "Severe Weather Threat: Tornadoes, Thunderstorms Pose Risk to Millions in Oklahoma and Southern Kansas", "body": "Millions face severe storms in the central US, with a high risk warning issued for Oklahoma and Kansas. Tornadoes, hurricane-force winds, and hail are expected, affecting nearly 10 million people and threatening schools and hospitals. Preparations, including seeking shelter in safe rooms, are crucial. Stormy weather is also expected in Colorado, Kansas City, Springfield, and the eastern US and South throughout the week.\n\nMillions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring. The National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Schools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and cancelled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbours know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,'' he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana. The risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n''If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,'' Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\" The high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday. The winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office. Colorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,'' noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. ''The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\" The entire week is looking stormy across the US. The eastern US and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "2024-05-346956512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:13:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:13:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:42:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/6/millions-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-o/", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "Millions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather - including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan. Murphy reported from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Salter reported from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writer Colleen Slevin contributed to this report from Denver, Colorado.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nWatch here: Central U.S. starts to pick up after deadly storm\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nWith the forecast, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts began canceling all after-school and evening activities.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\nREAD MORE: Tornadoes kill 4 in Oklahoma as severe weather prompts state of emergency in 12 counties\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: A storm system that resulted in mountain snow in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and heavy rain elsewhere in the West is colliding with a warm and humid air mass coming up from the Gulf of Mexico, Porter said.\n\nSevere weather was possible in southern Kansas after about 4 p.m. Monday. The dangerous weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan early in the day.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, {"uri": "8114574574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "23:34:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T23:34:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T23:34:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/06/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas/", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "By Alexa St. John, Sean Murphy and Jim Salter, Associated Press\n\nMonday, May 6, 2024 | 4:27 p.m.\n\nMillions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAs early evening approached, ominous wall clouds were forming in Oklahoma, with funnels emerging from them in rural areas. Meanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan. Murphy reported from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Salter reported from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writer Colleen Slevin contributed to this report from Denver, Colorado, and Heather Hollingsworth from Mission, Kansas.", "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-347060395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "00:32:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T00:32:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/storm-chasers-spot-tornado-in-oklahoma-as-hail-pelts-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come-1.6875488", "title": "Storm chasers spot tornado in Oklahoma as hail pelts Kansas. Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "Storm chasers spotted a tornado on the ground Monday in rural Oklahoma while large hail pelted parts of Kansas as forecasters issued a rare high risk warning for the two states with the possibility of long-track twisters.\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThe storm chasers detected several small funnels emerging from clouds before identifying a twister near the small 1,000-person Oklahoma town of Okeene. No damage was immediately reported, but the National Weather Service warned those in the area to take shelter.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of three inches (7.62 centimetres) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometres) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbours know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the centre is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 m.p.h. (49.71 km/h), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 m.p.h. (46.60 km/h) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighbourhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n------", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "https://www.ctvnews.ca/content/dam/ctvnews/en/images/2024/5/6/houston-flooding-1-6875489-1715021639746.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9543572", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": {"uri": "8114624984", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "00:39:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T00:39:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T00:38:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/2929805-tornado-and-hail-slam-oklahoma-and-kansas-with-more-severe-weather-predicted", "title": "Tornado and Hail Slam Oklahoma and Kansas, with More Severe Weather Predicted | Science-Environment", "body": "Tornadoes and large hail have hit Kansas and Oklahoma, with a high risk warning issued for both states. Forecasters warn of potentially long-track twisters. Damage has been reported, including large hail in Kansas. Over 3.4 million people in Oklahoma, Kansas, and Texas are under the highest level of tornado threat. Schools and businesses have closed in Oklahoma, and residents are urged to take shelter. Meteorologists say the risk is the highest in five years, and the storms could produce destructive tornadoes. The dangerous weather is expected to move east, bringing risks to Missouri through Tuesday.\n\nStorm chasers spotted a tornado on the ground Monday in rural Oklahoma while large hail pelted parts of Kansas as forecasters issued a rare high risk warning for the two states with the possibility of long-track twisters.\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring. The storm chasers detected several small funnels emerging from clouds before identifying a twister near the small 1,000-person Oklahoma town of Okeene. No damage was immediately reported, but the National Weather Service warned those in the area to take shelter.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimetres) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Schools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and cancelled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbours know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the centre is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,'' he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana. The risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\" The high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday. The winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office. Colorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,'' noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. ''The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\" The entire week is looking stormy across the US. The eastern US and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues. Bunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": The National Weather Service office there issued a tornado emergency alert Monday night for the nearby towns of Bartlesville, Dewey and Barnsdall.\n\nThe Weather Service warned \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward those towns, with wind gusts up to 70 mph.\n\nOther tornadoes had been spotted earlier in the evening near the 1,000-person town of Okeene, while another storm in Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour.\"\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nA dispatcher for Kingfisher County, Oklahoma, said there was a report of tornado damage to a single home, but it wasn't immediately known if anyone was in the home or if anyone was hurt. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 33}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Anomalies_and_Alternative_Science/Weather_Control", "label": "dmoz/Science/Anomalies and Alternative Science/Weather Control", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Folklore/Weather_Beliefs", "label": "dmoz/Society/Folklore/Weather Beliefs", "wgt": 15}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 66}], "image": "https://media.tegna-media.com/assets/CCT/images/a2a7c8c4-2bf3-41f3-b875-504f08c817c7/20240507T023247/a2a7c8c4-2bf3-41f3-b875-504f08c817c7_1140x641.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8114614388", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "00:29:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T00:29:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T00:24:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/storm-chasers-spot-tornado-oklahoma-002016527.html", "title": "Storm chasers spot tornado in Oklahoma as hail pelts Kansas. Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "Storm chasers spotted a tornado on the ground Monday in rural Oklahoma while large hail pelted parts of Kansas as forecasters issued a rare high risk warning for the two states with the possibility of long-track twisters.\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThe storm chasers detected several small funnels emerging from clouds before identifying a twister near the small 1,000-person Oklahoma town of Okeene. No damage was immediately reported, but the National Weather Service warned those in the area to take shelter.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to correct that heavy rain fell over southeastern Texas, not southwestern Texas.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan. Murphy reported from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Salter reported from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writer Colleen Slevin contributed to this report from Denver, Colorado, and Heather Hollingsworth from Mission, Kansas.\n\n___ The Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8114485215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:46:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:46:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:45:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.foxnews.com/us/millions-people-oklahoma-southern-kansas-risk-tornadoes-severe-thunderstorms", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "Fox News Flash top headlines are here. Check out what's clicking on Foxnews.com.\n\nMillions of people in the central United States must brace themselves for powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said Monday, issuing a rare high risk warning for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nWATCH: TORNADOES TEAR ACROSS AMERICA'S HEARTLAND, LEAVING CATASTROPHIC DESTRUCTION IN MULTIPLE STATES\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family {"uri": "8114400024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:18:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:18:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:18:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.wptv.com/weather/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-from-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk from tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "Millions of people in the central United States are bracing for powerful storms Monday including long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nWith the forecast, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts began canceling all after-school and evening activities. Oklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from potential hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be an atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.", "source": {"uri": "wptv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WPTV"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
