{"uri": "8116359218", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:57:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:57:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:56:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/indiana/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-more-weather/article_5e554a7a-2512-5afa-a5ce-10e2767b76ae.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for more weather", "body": "An Oklahoma State Highway Patrol trooper searches storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla.\n\nBy ALEXA ST. JOHN, SEAN MURPHY and JIM SALTER - Associated Press\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Weather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states on Tuesday to brace for dangerous storms, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nA tornado watch was issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana, southern Michigan and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour. Tuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States, ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one man who was still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the damage on Tuesday, said the tornado was rated by weather researchers as an EF4, which is described as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient, and we're going to rebuild,\" Stitt said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"We lost power. ... That's kind of the first indicator that things were real,\" he said. \"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden.\"\n\nThe weather soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. {"uri": "2024-05-348451839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:56:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:56:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:20:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.fox61.com/article/news/nation-world/severe-storms-michigan-indiana-ohio/507-c3b63fab-a1af-4726-9f73-b594c844e0a7", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "DETROIT -- Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area. A FedEx building was destroyed, debris left resting on delivery vehicles, but a company spokesperson said there were no serious injuries despite the severe damage.\n\nAn estimated 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility as of 9:30 p.m., said Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for the county administrator.\n\n\"First responders are actively looking for ways to get them out, but there are wires down in the building that they need the power company to clear before they can safely go in,\" Koopman said, citing the sheriff's office.\n\nMeanwhile, entire homes were destroyed in the Pavilion Estates mobile home park, she said.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center has cited more than a dozen reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nRELATED: Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. {"uri": "8116475483", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:27:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:27:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/5/8/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-storms", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for storms", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nThe National Weather Service said some tornadoes were spotted in southwestern Michigan on Tuesday, including two that blitzed parts of Portage, a city just south of Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area, while photos posted on Facebook showed severe roof damage at a FedEx building and debris resting on delivery vehicles. It wasn't immediately known if there were injuries.\n\nA tornado watch was also issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 mph (112.65 kph).\n\nTuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat as those Monday had, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nA deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe weather had soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But it was after dark when tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Storm"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-01", "textStart": 2039, "textEnd": 2046}], "sentiment": -0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 224, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8116419399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:12:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:12:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T00:11:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/national/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-storms/article_06e479f3-0b2f-57f8-b11a-a9f67fd8e12f.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for storms", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nThe National Weather Service said some tornadoes were spotted in southwestern Michigan on Tuesday, including two that blitzed parts of Portage, a city just south of Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area, while photos posted on Facebook showed severe roof damage at a FedEx building and debris resting on delivery vehicles. It wasn't immediately known if there were injuries.\n\nA tornado watch was also issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour.\n\nTuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat as those Monday had, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nA deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town.\"\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe weather had soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But it was after dark when tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8114744232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "03:05:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T03:05:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T03:04:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/storm-chasers-spot-tornado-in-oklahoma-as-hail-pelts-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come_991050.html", "title": "Millions of People Across Oklahoma, Southern Kansas Bracing for Tornadoes and Severe Thunderstorms", "body": "Storm chasers spotted a tornado on the ground Monday in rural Oklahoma while large hail pelted parts of Kansas as forecasters issued a rare high risk warning for the two states with the possibility of long-track twisters.\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nThe storm chasers detected several small funnels emerging from clouds before identifying a twister near the small 1,000-person Oklahoma town of Okeene. The National Weather Service said it was wrapped in rain and hard to see in the dark as it stayed on the ground.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service warned.\n\nA dispatcher for Kingfisher County, Oklahoma, said there was a report of tornado damage to a single home, but it wasn't immediately known if anyone was in the home or if anyone was hurt. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools, and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Mr. Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Mr. Porter said.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Mr. Bunting said.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Mr. Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Mr. Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the United States. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis, and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "8114788484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "03:55:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T03:55:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T03:53:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/texas/news/oklahoma-tornadoes-hail-kansas/", "title": "Tornadoes spotted in Oklahoma as dangerous storms move across Great Plains", "body": "Tornadoes touched down Monday evening in rural Oklahoma and large hail pelted parts of Kansas as an outbreak of dangerous storms brought the possibility of strong twisters staying on the ground for many miles.\n\nForecasters have issued a rare high-risk weather warning for the two states, the first for Oklahoma in five years.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service said.\n\nOklahoma was under a Particularly Dangerous Situation (PDS) watch, the second in just nine days. The PDS watch in the state last month resulted four deaths and 22 confirmed tornadoes.\n\nAt least four tornadoes had been spotted in north central Oklahoma, including one about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service office there issued a tornado emergency alert Monday night for the nearby towns of Bartlesville, Dewey and Barnsdall.\n\nThe Weather Service warned \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward those towns, with wind gusts up to 70 mph.\n\nOther tornadoes had been spotted earlier in the evening near the 1,000-person town of Okeene, while another storm in Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour.\"\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nA dispatcher for Kingfisher County, Oklahoma, said there was a report of tornado damage to a single home, but it wasn't immediately known if anyone was in the home or if anyone was hurt. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "8116605717", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:58:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:58:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:58:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/07/us-news/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in southwestern Michigan, northern Indiana and northwestern Ohio.\n\nForecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States.\n\nEight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.\n\nThe National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe town's mayor, Johnny Kelley, said one person died and one man was missing.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said.\n\n\"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing.\n\nThe powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said.\n\nAbout a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nIt later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph.\n\nStitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building.\n\nChunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nBoth the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday.\n\nThe last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the US.\n\nThe eastern US and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis {"uri": "8117071101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:32:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/may/08/powerful-storms-hit-central-united-states/", "title": "Powerful storms hit central United States", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90-100 mph damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30-40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75-80 percent of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one or two people who were still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town. ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered across the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph. Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBrian Yazzie helps clean his mother's home after it was damaged by a tornado Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nOklahoma State Highway Patrol troopers search storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nAn Oklahoma State Highway Patrol trooper searches storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nDebris and damage from powerful storms are seen. Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nTim and Joy King looks at their house that was destroyed by a tornado Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nA woman walks around debris and damage caused by powerful storms, Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nAn Oklahoma State Highway Patrol trooper searches storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. (Mike Simons/Tulsa World via AP)\n\nJoy King, left, and her granddaughter Crystal Maxey hug in front of King's house that was destroyed by a tornado Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. The two were looking for King's cats and salvaging what items they could. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas. The last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy. {"uri": "8115875689", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:51:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:51:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:51:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.heraldextra.com/top-headlines/2024/may/07/second-tornado-in-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-and-causes-1-death-as-powerful-storms-hit-central-us/", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75 to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one or two people who were still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "8117304815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:51:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:51:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:51:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.ksn.com/weather/weather-stories/ap-powerful-storms-bring-tornadoes-to-oklahoma-large-hail-to-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come/", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The city said in a news release that no serious injuries had been reported despite the twisters severely damaging homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nAn estimated 50 people were trapped inside the facility at one point because of downed power lines, authorities said. But FedEx spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMeanwhile, entire homes were destroyed in a nearby mobile home park.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center has cited more than a dozen reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest, including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend. ___ This story has been corrected to show that the comments from the FedEx spokesperson were made late Tuesday, not Monday.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Sarah Brumfield, Kathy McCormack, Beatrice Dupuy, Jim Salter, Heather Hollingsworth and Colleen "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 91}], "image": "https://www.ksn.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/13/2024/05/663b028da473e5.19079514.jpeg?strip=1&w=640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Detroit"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": {"uri": "2024-05-348299173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:02:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:02:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:44:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/news/national/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-more-weather/article_b3ceb1c8-44c9-5efa-81cc-73fb257de04a.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for more weather", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Weather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states on Tuesday to brace for dangerous storms, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nA tornado watch was issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana, southern Michigan and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour. Tuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States, ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one man who was still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the damage on Tuesday, said the tornado was rated by weather researchers as an EF4, which is described as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient, and we're going to rebuild,\" Stitt said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"We lost power. ... That's kind of the first indicator that things were real,\" he said. \"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden.\"\n\nThe weather soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-348338012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/climate-and-environment/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-storms-1.6876479", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for storms", "body": "Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nThe National Weather Service said some tornadoes were spotted in southwestern Michigan on Tuesday, including two that blitzed parts of Portage, a city just south of Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area, while photos posted on Facebook showed severe roof damage at a FedEx building and debris resting on delivery vehicles. It wasn't immediately known if there were injuries.\n\nA tornado watch was also issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour.\n\nTuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat as those Monday had, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nA deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 m.p.h. (145 to 161 km/h) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75 per cent to 80 per cent of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town.\"\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 m.p.h. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside US$45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometres) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe weather had soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But it was after dark when tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n------", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8114389415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "20:09:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T20:09:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T20:08:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://strangesounds.org/2024/05/severe-weather-alert-for-millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-as-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms-sweep-through.html", "title": "Severe weather alert for millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas as tornadoes and severe thunderstorms sweep through - Strange Sounds", "body": "Millions of people in the central United States are bracing for powerful storms Monday including long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed 4 and left thousands without power last week. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nWith the forecast, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts began canceling all after-school and evening activities.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: A storm system that resulted in mountain snow in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and heavy rain elsewhere in the West is colliding with a warm and humid air mass coming up from the Gulf of Mexico, Porter said.\n\nSevere weather was possible in southern Kansas after about 4 p.m. Monday. The dangerous weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan early in the day.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues. "http://strangesounds.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/Millions-of-people-across-Oklahoma-southern-Kansas-at-risk-of-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri":
