Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 55}], "image": "summary_large_image", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9543572", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039, "wgt": 219, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-348229642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "21:07:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T21:07:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T20:56:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/tornadoes-keep-tearing-through-us-including-a-rural-oklahoma-town-struck-twice-in-a-span/article_6888f329-70ea-5f01-8b7b-206d2f5cb244.html", "title": "Tornadoes keep tearing through US, including a rural Oklahoma town struck twice in a span of weeks", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAt least least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and at least one is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75 to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one person who was still missing, Kelley said. A second missing person was found safe, but injured, at a local hospital, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"We lost power. ... That's kind of the first indicator that things were real,\" he said. \"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden.\"\n\nAs soon as they knew they were in the clear, Macedo left the room to find glass and roofing debris littered across the floors.\n\n\"An AC unit went through the first floor on the southern side of the hotel,\" he said.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the Storm Prediction Center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of a few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph).\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8116582310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:35:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:35:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:32:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/after-oklahoma-severe-storms-and-deadly-tornadoes-strike-american-midwest-101715137669784.html", "title": "After Oklahoma, severe storms and deadly tornadoes strike American Midwest", "body": "Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area. A FedEx building was destroyed, debris left resting on delivery vehicles, but a company spokesperson said there were no serious injuries despite the severe damage.\n\nAn estimated 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility as of 9:30 p.m., said Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for the county administrator.\n\n\"First responders are actively looking for ways to get them out, but there are wires down in the building that they need the power company to clear before they can safely go in,\" Koopman said, citing the sheriff's office.\n\nMeanwhile, entire homes were destroyed in the Pavilion Estates mobile home park, she said.\n\nALSO READ| Biden administration halts ammunition delivery to Israel, US officials say it is intentional\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center has cited more than a dozen reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nALSO READ| AstraZeneca to withdraw Covid vaccine worldwide amid safety issues: Report\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nALSO READ| Harvey Weinstein is back at NYC's Rikers Island jail after hospital stay\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. {"uri": "2024-05-348418314", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:01:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:01:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T02:52:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.wtva.com/news/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/article_35ea4d12-7828-5ab2-a87f-75f2d2434d2c.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area. A FedEx building was destroyed, debris left resting on delivery vehicles, but a company spokesperson said there were no serious injuries despite the severe damage.\n\nAn estimated 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility as of 9:30 p.m., said Taylor Koopman, a spokesperson for the county administrator.\n\n\"First responders are actively looking for ways to get them out, but there are wires down in the building that they need the power company to clear before they can safely go in,\" Koopman said, citing the sheriff's office.\n\nMeanwhile, entire homes were destroyed in the Pavilion Estates mobile home park, she said.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center has cited more than a dozen reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "8115959761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:47:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/oklahoma-weather-alert-tornadoes-wreak-havoc-in-multiple-states-1-dead-amid-powerful-storms-101715099296179.html", "title": "Oklahoma weather alert: Tornadoes wreak havoc in multiple states, 1 dead amid powerful storms", "body": "The tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75 to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one or two people who were still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "8116437190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:35:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:35:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T00:34:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/midwest-to-brace-for-dangerous-storms-after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado/CICCPWRYBFAF7OKL5Z5YL3LLDA/", "title": "US Midwest braced for dangerous storms after deadly tornado", "body": "Weather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states to brace for dangerous storms, a day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nThe National Weather Service said some tornadoes were spotted in southwestern Michigan, including one that blitzed parts of Portage. Photos posted on Facebook showed severe roof damage at a FedEx building and debris resting on delivery vehicles. It wasn't immediately known if there were injuries.\n\nA tornado watch was issued on Tuesday afternoon for parts of northeast Indiana, southern Michigan and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 112km/h.\n\nTuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat as those on Monday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Centre cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening to early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heatwave.\n\nA deadly tornado that touched down on Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned on Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed towards Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 112km/h. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 145-161km/h damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged on Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it had evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man was missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely levelled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75-80 per cent of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About half a dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search on Tuesday morning to find a man who was still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with it \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us\".\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 64ha wax manufacturing facility in the community had also suffered heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nKevin Stitt, who toured the damage, said the tornado was rated by weather researchers as an EF4, which is described as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 320km/h. Stitt said he and legislative leaders had agreed to set aside US$45 million ($75m) in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient, and we're going to rebuild,\" Stitt said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville about 32km northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his co-worker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"We lost power ... that's kind of the first indicator that things were real,\" he said. \"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden.\"\n\nThe weather soured on Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour\", the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas such as Sulphur and Holdenville were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning. The last time such a warning was issued was on March 31 last year, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the south and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the US. The eastern US and the south are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. {"uri": "8114237938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:51:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:51:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:51:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://norfolkdailynews.com/news/national/news_national/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-of-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms/article_d6d33e38-0bce-11ef-84df-f7b5f4884b27.html", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "Millions of people in the central United States are bracing for powerful storms Monday including long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed 4 and left thousands without power last week. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nWith the forecast, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts began canceling all after-school and evening activities.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: A storm system that resulted in mountain snow in the Sierra Nevada Mountains and heavy rain elsewhere in the West is colliding with a warm and humid air mass coming up from the Gulf of Mexico, Porter said.\n\nSevere weather was possible in southern Kansas after about 4 p.m. Monday. The dangerous weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan early in the day.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Sean Murphy contributed to this report from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. {"uri": "2024-05-348376906", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:41:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:41:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:17:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/article_6888f329-70ea-5f01-8b7b-206d2f5cb244.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in southwestern Michigan, northern Indiana and northwestern Ohio. Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe town's mayor, Johnny Kelley, said one person died and one man was missing. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-01", "textStart": 1338, "textEnd": {"uri": "8116370516", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:10:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:10:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:10:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-more-weather/article_705b1070-0b91-5b49-885b-c045dda2bde5.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for more weather", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Weather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states on Tuesday to brace for dangerous storms, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nA tornado watch was issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana, southern Michigan and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour. Tuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States, ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one man who was still missing, Kelley said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the damage on Tuesday, said the tornado was rated by weather researchers as an EF4, which is described as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient, and we're going to rebuild,\" Stitt said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"We lost power. ... That's kind of the first indicator that things were real,\" he said. \"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden.\"\n\nThe weather soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United {"uri": "2024-05-347212363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "05:02:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T05:02:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T00:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/oklahoma/articles/2024-05-07/powerful-storms-bring-tornadoes-to-oklahoma-large-hail-to-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come", "title": "Powerful Storms Bring Tornadoes to Oklahoma, Large Hail to Kansas. Forecasts Warn More Is to Come", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Powerful storms have erupted in the central United States, bringing tornadoes to rural Oklahoma and large hail in parts of Kansas, with forecasters warning that the dangerous weather could stretch into the early hours of Tuesday amid a rare high-risk weather warning for the two states.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service said Monday.\n\nGusty winds and heavy rains began Monday afternoon, while tornadoes were spotted after dark skirting northern Oklahoma, including one that touched down about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa. At one point, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan, and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, and Colleen Slevin in Denver contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8115378306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "10:46:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T10:46:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T10:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/tornado-causes-extensive-damage-to-small-oklahoma-town-as-powerful-storms-hit-central-us/", "title": "Tornado causes extensive damage to small Oklahoma town as powerful storms hit central US - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that forecasters warned could stretch into the early hours of Tuesday.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nLaw enforcement officers and residents surveyed the damage in one neighborhood as lightning flashed and heavy rain came down, local TV news footage showed. The tornado had ripped off the roof of one house before spitting it back out onto the street. Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOTV that there were no confirmed fatalities as of 11 p.m. local time.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned earlier in the evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas were under a high-risk weather warning on Monday.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said such a warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-05-347198327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "04:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T04:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T04:34:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.wtaj.com/news/national-news/ap-powerful-storms-bring-tornadoes-to-oklahoma-large-hail-to-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come/", "title": "Powerful storms bring tornadoes to Oklahoma, large hail to Kansas. Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Powerful storms have erupted in the central United States, bringing tornadoes to rural Oklahoma and large hail in parts of Kansas, with forecasters warning that the dangerous weather could stretch into the early hours of Tuesday amid a rare high-risk weather warning for the two states.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service said Monday.\n\nGusty winds and heavy rains began Monday afternoon, while tornadoes were spotted after dark skirting northern Oklahoma, including one that touched down about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa. At one point, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan, and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, and Colleen Slevin in Denver contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. {"uri": "8116482272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:36:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:36:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:35:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/indiana/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/article_5e554a7a-2512-5afa-a5ce-10e2767b76ae.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "An Oklahoma State Highway Patrol trooper searches storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla.\n\nBy ALEXA ST. JOHN, SEAN MURPHY and JIM SALTER - Associated Press\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in southwestern Michigan, northern Indiana and northwestern Ohio. Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe town's mayor, Johnny Kelley, said one person died and one man was missing. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. JOHN\n\nUpdated 10:51 AM CDT, May 6, 2024\n\nMillions of people in the central United States could see powerful storms Monday including long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed 4 and left thousands without power last week.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas. The last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nBill Bunting, the center's deputy director, said a high risk from the Storm Prediction Center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. {"uri": "8114332507", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:14:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:14:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:14:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/millions-of-people-across-oklahoma-southern-kansas-at-risk-of-tornadoes-and-severe-thunderstorms-1.6875488", "title": "Millions of people across Oklahoma, southern Kansas at risk of tornadoes and severe thunderstorms", "body": "Millions of people in the central United States are bracing for powerful storms Monday including long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail, forecasters said.\n\nMuch of Oklahoma and parts of Kansas are at the greatest risk of bad weather -- including areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas under threat of severe weather, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said. Forecasters there issued a rare high risk for central Oklahoma and southern Kansas.\n\nWith the forecast, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts began canceling all after-school and evening activities. Oklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most state workers across the state leave early on Monday.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Mo., and Lincoln, Neb.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph, according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph, created by the same system that has raised the risk of severe weather on the Plains, have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico that is fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the U.S. National Weather Service's Denver area office.\n\nThe moisture is not being pulled into Colorado though which is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nSevere weather was possible in southern Kansas after about 4 p.m. Monday. The dangerous weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" said Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water {"uri": "8114945248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "06:10:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T06:10:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T06:09:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/powerful-storms-bring-tornadoes-to-oklahoma-large-hail-to-kansas/article68148266.ece", "title": "Powerful storms bring tornadoes to Oklahoma, large hail to Kansas", "body": "Gusty winds and heavy rains began on Monday afternoon, while tornadoes were spotted after dark skirting northern Oklahoma, including one that touched down about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa.\n\nPowerful storms have erupted in the central United States, bringing tornadoes to rural Oklahoma and large hail in parts of Kansas, with forecasters warning that the dangerous weather could stretch into the early hours of Tuesday (May 7), amid a rare high-risk weather warning for the two states.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service said on May 6.\n\nGusty winds and heavy rains began on Monday afternoon, while tornadoes were spotted after dark skirting northern Oklahoma, including one that touched down about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa.\n\n\"At one point, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail, three inches (7.6 centimetres) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Centre, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on May 6.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbours know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Mr. Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Centre, said a high risk warning from the centre is not something seen every day or every spring. \"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office. Colorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding on Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighbourhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nRead Comments", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
