{"uri": "8114857744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "04:59:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T04:59:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T04:58:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/tornadoes-storms-weather-oklahoma-kansas-t75736", "title": "Powerful storms bring tornadoes to Oklahoma, large hail to Kansas. Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY -- Powerful storms have erupted in the central United States, bringing tornadoes to rural Oklahoma and large hail in parts of Kansas, with forecasters warning that the dangerous weather could stretch into the early hours of Tuesday amid a rare high-risk weather warning for the two states.\n\n\"You can't rely on waiting to see tornadoes before sheltering tonight,\" the National Weather Service said Monday.\n\nGusty winds and heavy rains began Monday afternoon, while tornadoes were spotted after dark skirting northern Oklahoma, including one that touched down about a 45-minute drive north of Tulsa. At one point, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan, and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, and Colleen Slevin in Denver contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. At one point, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,'' the National Weather Service said.\n\nThroughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimetres) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Centre, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbours know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Centre, said a high risk warning from the centre is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,'' he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fuelling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the US. The eastern US and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighbourhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-05-348390093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "02:07:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T02:07:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:17:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/article_d4d85cae-c41e-5469-b17c-737b09e40c0d.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in southwestern Michigan, northern Indiana and northwestern Ohio. Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe town's mayor, Johnny Kelley, said one person died and one man was missing. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-347857521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:26:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:26:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wxow.com/news/second-tornado-in-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-and-causes-1-death-as-powerful-storms/article_519da05d-cf55-530b-b404-3bd0885cf9f8.html", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Osage County Undersheriff Gary Upton said by telephone.\n\n\"It is a small town and it just pretty much went right through the center of it,\" he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8116225069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:36:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:36:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T20:36:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/tornadoes-keep-tearing-through-us-including-a-rural-oklahoma-town-struck-twice-in-a-span/article_705b1070-0b91-5b49-885b-c045dda2bde5.html", "title": "Tornadoes keep tearing through US, including a rural Oklahoma town struck twice in a span of weeks", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said.\n\n\"There are several homes destroyed, completely leveled,\" he said. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community. I know 75 to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, including a firefighter who was taken to a hospital with chest pains, he said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAuthorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning to find one person who was still missing, Kelley said. A second missing person was found safe, but injured, at a local hospital, he said.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage, Kelley said.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph).\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSalter reported from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Alexa St. John in Detroit; Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. "Midwestern United States"}, "location": null}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Las Vegas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Oklahoma City"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United {"uri": "8115757727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:36:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:36:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:36:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/oklahoma-town-sees-second-tornado-in-5-weeks-as-deadly-storms-hit-central-u-s", "title": "Oklahoma town sees second tornado in 5 weeks as deadly storms hit central U.S.", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nREAD MORE: Hundreds rescued from Texas floods as more storms move through Houston area\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Osage County Undersheriff Gary Upton said by telephone.\n\n\"It is a small town and it just pretty much went right through the center of it,\" he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nREAD MORE: Houston area braces for worse flooding after heavy storms, with more rain on the way\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, {"uri": "8115812551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:11:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:11:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:11:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/07/second-tornado-in-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-an/", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central U.S.", "body": "By Alexa St. John, Sean Murphy and Jim Salter, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, May 7, 2024 | 7:59 a.m.\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nOne person died in Barnsdall and at least one is missing, Osage County Undersheriff Gary Upton said by telephone.\n\n\"It is a small town and it just pretty much went right through the center of it,\" he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nA survey team planned to head out Tuesday to evaluate damage in Barnsdall and Bartlesville, and in Arkansas, according to Joe Sellers, a meteorologist with the weather service's office in Tulsa, Oklahoma.\n\nThe storm prediction center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at [email protected].\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8116476921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:28:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:28:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:28:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-storms-bring-twisters-to-the-midwest/article_0ae60260-6b11-5ffb-b843-051e8813b601.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, storms bring twisters to the Midwest", "body": "An Oklahoma State Highway Patrol trooper searches storm damage Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla.\n\nBy ALEXA ST. JOHN, SEAN MURPHY and JIM SALTER - Associated Press\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in southwestern Michigan, northern Indiana and northwestern Ohio. Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois Bloomington provides street resurfacing update Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release Pitching talents of Pontiac's Henry Brummel attracting professional scouts Normal man detained in home invasion, sexual assault case\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe town's mayor, Johnny Kelley, said one person died and one man was missing. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9545208", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-01", "textStart": 2501, "textEnd": 2508}], "sentiment": -0.403921568627451, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8116599958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:52:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:52:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:51:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/deadly-oklahoma-tornado-trail-of-damage-barnsdall-bartlesville-portage-michigan/", "title": "Storms batter Midwest one day after tornado leaves at least 1 dead in Oklahoma", "body": "Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nOverall Monday night and early Tuesday, at least 22 tornadoes were reported by the National Weather Service across seven states in the Great Plains and Central U.S. The severe weather threat was expected to continue Tuesday night into Wednesday, according to Alex Wilson, meteorologist for The Weather Channel, who reported that Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky were at risk.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The Kalamazoo County Sheriff's Office said there were \"multiple trees down and wires throughout\" Portage and nearby Pavilion Township. A Portage city spokesperson said in a statement that there was significant damage to homes and businesses, but no immediate reports of serious injuries.\n\nPhotos posted to social media showed major damage to a FedEx building in the Portage area.\n\nIn a statement to CBS News, a FedEx spokesperson confirmed its facility was damaged, but said there were \"no serious injuries.\"\n\n\"We continue to assess the damage, and we are implementing contingency plans to lessen any potential impacts on service,\" the statement read.\n\nPortage Director of Public Safety Nicholas Armold told CBS News all FedEx employees were accounted for and none had been trapped beneath the wreckage of the building.\n\nMore than 20,000 people lost power in the Portage area, Consumers Energy said Tuesday night. The company estimated most would be without power until 10 p.m. on Wednesday.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo, St. Joseph, Branch, and Cass counties on Tuesday night after the storm brought \"large hail up to four inches in diameter and at least two confirmed tornadoes,\" she said in a statement.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in Bartlesville, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage. It later posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries, and they were being taken to other facilities.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, who was staying at the hotel, said he was ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas including Sulphur and Holdenville were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state capital of Oklahoma City, was still activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather got dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas were under a high-risk weather warning on Monday. Bill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said such a warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph were blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds were being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that was also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado wasn't at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern The nearby city of Bartlesville also took a \"direct hit\" from a funnel, according to Washington County Emergency Director Kary Cox.\n\nStephen Nehrenz, a meteorologist at CBS Tulsa affiliate KOTV, said on social media late Monday that, \"The Hampton Inn in Bartlesville took a hit from tonight's tornado. Reports are they lost most of the building's roof. So far it sounds like most everyone there is okay from what we've heard initially.\"\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in Bartlesville, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nLaw enforcement officers and residents surveyed the damage in one Barnsdall neighborhood as lightning flashed and heavy rain came down, local TV news footage showed. The tornado had ripped off the roof one house before spitting it back out onto the street.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nCBS Tulsa affiliate KOTV cited Osage County Emergency Management as saying there were confirmed reports of numerous injuries and widespread damage in Barnsdall. OCEM said many people were believed to be trapped in their homes and that downed power lines and concern about possible gas leaks were making it difficult to respond. County officials are working to clear the roads.\n\nSearch and rescue efforts were underway at Osage Nation Reservation, authorities said.\n\nSome 17,000 homes and businesses were in the dark in Oklahoma as of 5:45 a.m. local time.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned earlier in the evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph. Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas including Sulphur and Holdenville were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state capital of Oklahoma City, was still activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe weather service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat of tornadoes Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather got dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas were under a high-risk weather warning on Monday.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said such a warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph were blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds were being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that was also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado wasnlt at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "2024-05-347734837", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:46:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:46:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.fultonsun.com/news/2024/may/07/tornado-causes-extensive-damage-to-oklahoma-town-and-1-death-as-powerful-storms-hit-central-us/", "title": "Tornado causes extensive damage to Oklahoma town and 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds "https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/img/photos/2024/05/07/oktornado_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9543572", "eventUri": {"uri": "8114622633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "00:36:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T00:36:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T00:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/storm-chasers-spot-tornado-in-oklahoma-as-hail-pelts-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to/article_7436cfad-16f8-58c1-9b36-18a4d220940c.html", "title": "Storm chasers spot tornado in Oklahoma as hail pelts Kansas. Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "By Alexa St. John, Sean Murphy And Jim Salter The Associated Press\n\nStorm chasers spotted a tornado on the ground Monday in rural Oklahoma while large hail pelted parts of Kansas as forecasters issued a rare high risk warning for the two states with the possibility of long-track twisters.\n\nThe greatest risk of damaging weather includes areas in Oklahoma, such as Sulphur and Holdenville, still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe storm chasers detected several small funnels emerging from clouds before identifying a twister near the small 1,000-person Oklahoma town of Okeene. No damage was immediately reported, but the National Weather Service warned those in the area to take shelter.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMeanwhile, apple-sized hail of 3 inches (7.62 centimeters) in diameter was reported near Ellinwood, Kansas, a town of about 2,000 residents 100 miles (161 kilometers) northwest of Wichita.\n\nThe National Weather Service said that more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat for tornadoes.\n\nIn all, nearly 10 million people live in areas that could be affected, the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nSchools and colleges across the state, including the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma City Public Schools and several metro-area school districts, shut down early and canceled late afternoon and evening classes and activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms, and the state's commissioner of public safety told state agencies to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the far western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail and letting his neighbors know they can come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nTucker said there's not much you can do to protect cattle from severe storms, but he said the animals tend to know when the weather turns threatening.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said a high risk from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe last time a high risk was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe risk on Monday in parts of the southern Plains is the worst in five years, AccuWeather Chief Meteorologist Jon Porter said.\n\n\"If you look at a meteorology textbook about how to get a significant tornado outbreak in the southern Plains, all the ingredients you need are here today,\" Porter said.\n\nCities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nThe number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south-central Kansas, Bunting said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe expected thunderstorms could produce winds up to and potentially exceeding 80 mph (49.71 kph), according to Porter. Even worse, those \"supercell\" storms can produce destructive tornadoes.\n\n\"The kinds of tornadoes that this storm can produce are particularly intense, and they can be long-lasting,\" Porter said. \"These are the tornadoes that sometimes can last for 45 minutes or an hour, even more, creating paths of destruction as they move along.\"\n\nThe high risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph (46.60 kph) have been blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds are being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that is also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, said Greg Heavener, warning coordination meteorologist at the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado is not at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms, he said.\n\nThe dangerous Plains weather will move east, potentially creating overnight risk in places like Kansas City and Springfield in Missouri through early Tuesday, Porter said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This is not going to be a atmospheric setup where the sun is going to go down and the thunderstorms are going to wane and there's going to be no additional risk,\" noted Northern Illinois University meteorology professor Victor Gensini. \"The risk for tornadoes tonight will continue into the evening and overnight hours making it very challenging.\"\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\n___\n\nThis story has been updated to correct that heavy rain fell over southeastern Texas, not southwestern Texas.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit, Michigan. Murphy reported from Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Salter reported from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writer Colleen Slevin contributed to this report from Denver, Colorado, and Heather Hollingsworth from Mission, Kansas.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\n___ The Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Louis", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "St. Louis"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "St. Louis"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Detroit"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Atmospheric_Sciences", "label": "dmoz/Science/Earth Sciences/Atmospheric Sciences", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 76}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/thestar.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/c5/9c511208-50ec-502a-b383-d779e8fcf709/6637fcb16bbaa.image.jpg?crop=1280%2C672%2C0%2C90&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9543572", "eventUri": "eng-9545208", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 204, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8116423571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:17:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:17:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T00:17:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/after-deadly-oklahoma-tornado-forecasters-warn-midwest-residents-to-brace-for-storms/article_1fe9f943-1d03-559a-ac9a-dcc0ea930525.html", "title": "After deadly Oklahoma tornado, forecasters warn Midwest residents to brace for storms", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.\n\nThe National Weather Service said some tornadoes were spotted in southwestern Michigan on Tuesday, including two that blitzed parts of Portage, a city just south of Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area, while photos posted on Facebook showed severe roof damage at a FedEx building and debris resting on delivery vehicles. It wasn't immediately known if there were injuries.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nA tornado watch was also issued Tuesday afternoon for portions of northeast Indiana and northwest Ohio with the possibility of tornadoes, large hail and wind gusts of up to 70 miles per hour.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTuesday's storms were not expected to pose as intense a threat as those Monday had, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nA deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak could not be turned off due to storm damage.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOne person died in the town and one man is missing, Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\nAerial videos from Barnsdall showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\n\"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is this is a small community,\" Kelley said. \"I know 75% to 80% of the people in this town.\"\n\nFirst responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said. About a half dozen people suffered injuries, he said.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being taken to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nGov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles (32 kilometers) northeast.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris was scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with smashed-out windows.\n\nMatthew Macedo, 30, who was staying at the hotel, said he rushed with his coworker to the hotel lobby after hearing the tornado sirens and was then ushered into the hotel laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nThe weather had soured earlier Monday, bringing gusty winds and rain. But it was after dark when tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas; Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas; Colleen Slevin in Denver; Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire; Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland; and Ed White in Detroit contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations.
