{"uri": "2024-05-347624360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:16:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:16:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T06:30:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/7/tornado-generates-extensive-damage-to-oklahoma-tow/", "title": "Tornado causes extensive damage to Oklahoma town and 1 death as powerful storms hit central U.S.", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. {"uri": "2024-05-348496268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "04:59:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T04:59:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T04:48:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.fox16.com/news/national/ap-storms-battering-the-midwest-bring-tornadoes-hail-and-strong-winds/", "title": "Storms battering the Midwest bring tornadoes, hail and strong winds", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region that forecasters warned could stretch into Wednesday morning.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. Portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nThere were no serious injuries immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBefore Monday night's powerful tornado touched down, the National Weather Service had warned that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" north of Tulsa was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-347682980", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:03:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:03:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:56:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://wgntv.com/weather/ap-powerful-storms-bring-tornadoes-to-oklahoma-large-hail-to-kansas-forecasts-warn-more-is-to-come/", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday.\n\nAt least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries, because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 miles per hour. Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind-farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail of 3 inches in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said.\n\nHe said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest, including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "2024-05-349144706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:30:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:30:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:10:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.localsyr.com/news/national/ap-storms-battering-the-midwest-bring-tornadoes-hail-and-strong-winds/", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-349101983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:54:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:54:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.recordherald.com/2024/05/08/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still {"uri": "2024-05-348497639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:01:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:01:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T00:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-05-08/storms-battering-the-midwest-bring-tornadoes-hail-and-strong-winds", "title": "Storms Battering the Midwest Bring Tornadoes, Hail and Strong Winds", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region that forecasters warned could stretch into Wednesday morning.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. Portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nThere were no serious injuries immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBefore Monday night's powerful tornado touched down, the National Weather Service had warned that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" north of Tulsa was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-05-348537600", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:49:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:49:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T05:32:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/storms-battering-the-midwest-bring-tornadoes-hail-and-strong-winds/article_42c5a277-8c92-5312-80cc-7b604a3275cd.html", "title": "Storms battering the Midwest bring tornadoes, hail and strong winds", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms continued to barrel through the Midwest early Wednesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes that forecasters warned could spill out of the region.\n\nThe tornadoes were first spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nThere were no serious injuries immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBefore Monday night's powerful tornado touched down, the National Weather Service had warned that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" north of Tulsa was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. {"uri": "8117489566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:45:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:45:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:44:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/", "title": "Severe Storms Batter The Midwest, Including Reported Tornadoes That Shredded A FedEx Facility", "body": "Tornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. {"uri": "8117023642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "09:04:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T09:04:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:03:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/08/tornadoes-tear-across-midwest/", "title": "Tornadoes tear across Midwest", "body": "DETROIT -- Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nForecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo. The sheriff's office there said multiple trees and power lines were down in the area. A FedEx building was destroyed, debris left resting on delivery vehicles, but a company spokesperson said there were no serious injuries despite the severe damage.\n\nAn estimated 50 people were trapped inside the facility at one point because of downed power lines, authorities said. But FedEx spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMeanwhile, entire homes were destroyed in a nearby mobile home park.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center has cited more than a dozen reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.\n\nThe deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley said one person was dead while one man was missing after Monday's twister. Authorities launched a secondary search Tuesday morning for the missing man.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported.\n\nAerial videos showed several well-built homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off and damaged walls still standing. The powerful twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with wind speeds up to 200 mph. Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Ed White of The Assocaited Press.\n\nDebris and damage from powerful storms are pictured, Tuesday, May 7, 2024, in Barnsdall, Okla. A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through the small Oklahoma town. {"uri": "8117642540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:22:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:22:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:21:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/may/08/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reporte/", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "Brad Devereaux/Kalamazoo Gazette via AP\n\nFedEx trucks sit outside a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Mich., Tuesday, May 7, 2024.\n\nBy Ed White, Alexa St. John and Sean Murphy, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, May 8, 2024 | 8:12 a.m.\n\nDETROIT -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "2024-05-349133904", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:21:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:21:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_33b5cf7d-68db-5652-a310-e869d20a17a4.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "Debris is seen at a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Michigan, on Tuesday.\n\nDETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. Find AP's standards for working with philanthropies, a list of supporters and funded coverage areas at AP.org.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "8115535404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:19:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:19:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:19:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/b8def43f7b0402d12911573ea5b4233b/second-tornado-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-and-causes-1", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak that could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being transported to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east into on Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, Colleen Slevin in Denver, Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire, and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. {"uri": "2024-05-349087928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:41:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:41:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:10:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_42c5a277-8c92-5312-80cc-7b604a3275cd.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. {"uri": "8115164324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "08:38:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T08:38:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T08:38:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tornado-northeast-oklahoma-trail-of-damage-barnsdall-bartlesville/", "title": "Tornado tears through northeast Oklahoma, leaves trail of damage", "body": "A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small northeast Oklahoma city, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person city of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, Monday night. The nearby city of Bartlesville also took a \"direct hit\" from a funnel, according to Washington County Emergency Director Kary Cox.\n\nStephen Nehrenz, a meteorologist at CBS Tulsa affiliate KOTV, said on social media late Monday that, \"The Hampton Inn in Bartlesville took a hit from tonight's tornado. Reports are they lost most of the building's roof. So far it sounds like most everyone there is okay from what we've heard initially.\"\n\nLaw enforcement officers and residents surveyed the damage in one Barnsdall neighborhood as lightning flashed and heavy rain came down, local TV news footage showed. The tornado had ripped off the roof one house before spitting it back out onto the street. Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOTV there were no confirmed fatalities as of 11 p.m. local time.\n\nThe station said cited Osage County Emergency Management as saying there were confirmed reports of numerous injuries and widespread damage. OCEM said many people were believed to be trapped in their homes and that downed power lines and concern about possible gas leaks were making it difficult to respond. County officials are working to clear the roads.\n\nSearch and rescue efforts were underway at Osage Nation Reservation, authorities said.\n\nSome 28,000 homes and businesses were in the dark in Oklahoma as of 3:30 a.m. local time.\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned earlier in the evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph. Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas including Sulphur and Holdenville were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state capital of Oklahoma City, was still activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe weather service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat of tornadoes Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect them from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather got dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas were under a high-risk weather warning on Monday.\n\nBill Bunting, deputy director of the Storm Prediction Center, said such a warning from the center is not something seen every day or every spring.\n\n\"It's the highest level of threat we can assign,\" he said.\n\nThe last time it was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe increased risk is due to an unusual confluence: Winds gusting up to around 75 mph were blasting through Colorado's populated Front Range region, including the Denver area, on Monday.\n\nThe winds were being created by a low pressure system north of Colorado that was also pulling up moisture from the Gulf of Mexico, fueling the risk of severe weather on the Plains, according to the National Weather Service's Denver-area office.\n\nColorado wasnlt at risk of tornadoes or thunderstorms.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds {"uri": "8115513075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:07:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:07:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:07:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/07/second-tornado-in-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-and-causes-1-death-as-powerful-storms-hit-central-us/", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central U.S.", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak that could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being transported to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east into on Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations.
