{"uri": "8115432807", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:18:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:18:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:17:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/weather/tornado-causes-damage-one-death-in-oklahoma/3534824/", "title": "One death reported after tornado causes damage to Oklahoma towns", "body": "At least one death was reported after a tornado ripped through Oklahoma on Monday and Tuesday\n\nA tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph. Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds A tornado emergency was issued for Union City -- marking the first tornado emergency for the state on record, going back to 1999.\n\nThe National Weather Service warned there was a \"confirmed large and destructive tornado\" over Union City at 6:11 p.m. ET Tuesday.\n\nAfter more than a dozen tornadoes were reported in the Plains overnight into Tuesday, the tornado threat moved into Ohio Valley and parts of the southern Great Lakes Tuesday afternoon and evening. Some 35 million Americans are in the storm zone, from Chicago to Nashville, Tennessee.\n\nA tornado watch was issued for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Kentucky into Tuesday night. A few tornadoes, damaging gusts up to 70 mph and baseball-sized hail are likely.\n\nKentucky Gov. Andy Beshear urged residents to prepare for the severe weather -- including \"potentially significant tornadoes,\" flooding, hail and high winds -- expected to hit much of the state over the next few days.\n\n\"We have been through all of those and we have seen how deadly they can be,\" Beshear said during a press briefing Tuesday. \"So we need everyone to take action now by making a plan to keep yourself and your family safe.\"\n\nThe latest tornado threat comes as at least 20 tornadoes were reported in seven states overnight into Tuesday.\n\nThe twisters were reported in Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Tennessee.\n\nOne of the hardest-hit areas in the storm was Barnsdall and Bartlesville, Oklahoma, north of Tulsa. The National Weather Service in Tulsa found low-end EF4 damage near Barnsdall during the tornado survey process on Tuesday.\n\nOne person was killed and several injured in Barnsdall, which sustained \"significant damage\" due to the tornado, according to Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley.\n\n\"We need a lot of prayers,\" Kelley told reporters during a press briefing following the tornado.\n\nSome 60 to 70 homes in the small town were \"totally destroyed,\" among approximately 350 destroyed statewide, Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt said.\n\nApproximately 25 people were rescued following an initial search, Kelley said. One person remains unaccounted for as another search effort got underway Tuesday, he said.\n\nThe missing man was in his trailer home talking to his son on the phone just minutes before the tornado came through, according to Stitt. Police K-9 units are involved in the search, he said.\n\n\"We're just praying a miracle happens,\" Stitt told reporters during a press briefing Tuesday evening.\n\nStitt has declared a state of emergency for several counties in the state due to the severe weather.\n\nThe destructive tornado was the second to hit Barnsdall in recent weeks.\n\n\"It's a devastating blow to the people in the {"uri": "8117392048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:44:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:44:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:44:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/486324/Severe-storms-batter-the-Midwest-including-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-FedEx-facility", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Debris is seen from a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Mich., Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (Brad Devereaux/Kalamazoo Gazette via AP)\n\nSevere storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nThe tornadoes were first spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. And it's a day to take very, very seriously,\" he said.\n\nOther cities that could see stormy weather include Kansas City, Missouri and Lincoln, Nebraska.\n\nBunting said the number of storms and their intensity should increase quickly in the evening hours across western parts of Oklahoma and up into south central Kansas.\n\nBunting advises people in the affected areas to develop a severe weather plan early in the day.\n\n\"Make sure that you have ways to communicate with your family members,\" he said. \"Make sure everyone knows where their shelters are,,\" and how they can continue to receive warnings.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati could see severe thunderstorms later in the week, where more than 21 million people live.\n\nMeanwhile, early Monday heavy rains hit southwestern Texas, especially the Houston area, leaving neighborhoods flooded and leading to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. {"uri": "8115461592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "11:36:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T11:36:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T11:36:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/tornado-causes-extensive-damage-to-oklahoma-town-and-1-death-as-powerful-storms-hit-central-us/", "title": "Tornado causes extensive damage to Oklahoma town and 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY, May 7, (AP): A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. The damaging effects of the tornado were also witnessed in Bartlesville, another rural community just north of Tulsa.\n\nOklahoma Highway Patrol reported around 30-40 homes were damaged in the Barnsdall area, which was also hit by a tornado earlier on April 1, according to the state's Department of Emergency Management. Officials also reported a natural gas leak in Barnsdall.\n\nLive updates:Severe weather threatens central US after deadly storms hit Oklahoma\n\nDrone video shows damage\n\nSocial media videos and {"uri": "2024-05-348373711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:35:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:35:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:25:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/1-dead-oklahoma-tornadoes-millions-132158086.html", "title": "Several twisters hit Michigan, where a rare tornado emergency was declared for one city", "body": "Several twisters hit Michigan, where a rare tornado emergency was declared for one cityMary Gilbert and Steve AlmasyUpdated May 8, 2024 at 3:25 AM\n\nSeveral tornadoes hit Michigan on Tuesday evening, with one city in the southern part of the state under a rare tornado emergency as strong storms pushed through.\n\nThe emergency for Union City went into effect just after 6 p.m. ET, when \"a large and destructive tornado\" was over the city, about 10 miles northwest of Coldwater and moving northeast at 45 mph, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nEmergency responders' radios crackled with reports of possible destruction as the intense storms pushed through, but officials have not yet shared reports about the damage. Photos on social media have shown some damage to buildings.\n\nThe National Weather Service has issued tornado and severe thunderstorm warnings for southern parts of Michigan. \"Severe storms are still tracking between Kalamazoo and Jackson. Tornadoes and large hail are the main threats,\" the National Weather Service Grand Rapids said.\n\n\"Stay home\" and \"Please stay off the roads. First responders are stuck in gridlock,\" the city of Portage pleaded with its residents.\n\nSeveral tornado warnings are also in effect from western Ohio to eastern Indiana.\n\nThe severe weather came a day after destructive storms roared through the Plains Monday, unloading at least one deadly tornado, giant hail and hurricane-force wind gusts. As some communities pick up the pieces, others had been preparing Tuesday for the threat of strong twisters in the Midwest.\n\n* One killed, several injured Monday: At least one person is dead and several others are injured after a tornado tore through Oklahoma's Osage and Washington counties Monday night, Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden said in an on-air interview with CNN affiliate KOKI. Extensive damage occurred to dozens of homes between Barnsdall and Bartlesville. A search was ongoing in Barnsdall Tuesday for \"one or two\" people still unaccounted for, the town's mayor Johnny Kelley said at a news conference.\n\n* Tornado damage in at least two other states: A tornado caused \"considerable damage\" in Sullivan, Missouri, late Monday night according to storm reports. The extent of the damage is unclear, but images from the scene showed buildings filleted by the twister. Another tornado tore through parts of DeKalb County, Tennessee, and damaged at least a dozen homes in the Smithville area early Monday afternoon, officials told CNN.\n\n* More than 200 storm reports: There were 244 storm reports Monday, including 17 tornado reports, according to the Storm Prediction Center. Hail the size of softballs slammed down in Kansas while baseball-sized hail pummeled Oklahoma. Wind gusts of 70 mph or greater were recorded in Nebraska and Kansas while an 82-mph wind gust occurred near Chester, Oklahoma.\n\n* Rare high risk issued: Monday marked the first high - Level 5 of 5 - risk issued for the US by the Storm Prediction Center in more than a year. It was the first time in nearly five years Oklahoma was under such an extreme risk and the first time in nearly seven years in Kansas.\n\n* More storms to come: Level 3 of 5 risks for severe thunderstorms are in place for parts of the US on Tuesday and Wednesday, with millions at risk of damaging wind gusts, hail and tornadoes.\n\nTown hit by tornado for the second time in five weeks\n\nMonday night's triggered a tornado emergency for Barnsdall, Oklahoma, but residents here were all too familiar with the situation. It was the second damaging tornado in just over a month to hit the town, which was struck by an EF1 on April 1.\n\nUnder the cover of darkness Monday night, the large and destructive tornado barreled through the town.\n\nDorothy Aultz and her son Carl Kelley were at Dorothy's Barnsdall home when the tornado hit. Dorothy is elderly and receiving hospice care, Carl told CNN, so he went to his mother's home to protect her during the storm.\n\nWith a tornado on the way and no basement to shelter in, Carl had to improvise. He placed blankets on the bathroom floor, placed Dorothy on them and laid on top of her to protect her from debris.\n\nThe tornado tore through the home and destroyed most of it, but the bathroom held strong. Both mother and son made through the experience unscathed and were rescued from the rubble.\n\nThey were among the roughly two dozen people rescued from their damaged or destroyed homes Monday night, Kelley, the city's mayor, said in a news conference Tuesday.\n\nThe full extent of the tornado's destruction in Barnsdall didn't become clear until the sun rose Tuesday. Much of the town has \"significant damage;\" a nursing home was damaged and evacuated; and several homes were \"completely leveled,\" Kelley said.\n\nBut it's the loss of a man Kelley knew well in this close-knit community of 1,400 that will stick with him, he said.\n\n\"To me, the material things are material, you can replace them,\" Kelley said. \"The loss of life, it's something that's forever.\"\n\nTornado threat shifts to Midwest, Tennessee Valley Tuesday\n\nStrong storms shifted east on Tuesday and have ushered in a renewed threat of damaging wind gusts, large hail and tornadoes.\n\nSevere thunderstorms got underway Tuesday afternoon in parts of Illinois but will expand across much of the Midwest and Tennessee Valley through the evening.\n\nNearly 13 million people here are at risk of a few strong tornadoes of at least EF2 strength. The Level 3 of 5 risk area includes large portions of Indiana, including Indianapolis; Kentucky, including Louisville; and Ohio, including Columbus.\n\nDamaging winds and hail are possible outside of the highest risk area across a huge portion of the eastern US.\n\nMillions are at risk of damaging storms once again on Wednesday, including areas hard-hit by Monday's storms.\n\nAn expansive Level 3 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms is in place from northeastern Texas and eastern Oklahoma to much of Kentucky and Tennessee. Damaging wind gusts, hail bigger than baseballs and tornadoes are all possible within Wednesday's storms.\n\nSome strong tornadoes are possible, mainly from Missouri through central Kentucky and northern Tennessee. St. Louis and Nashville are just two cities at risk of powerful tornadoes.\n\nTorrential rainfall may also occur within any storm Wednesday and trigger flash flooding. A Level 2 of 4 risk of excessive rainfall is in place for a large portion of the Tennessee and Ohio valleys, according to the Weather Prediction Center. Rainfall rates could approach 1 to 2 inches per hour in the heaviest storms.\n\nCNN's Joe Sutton, Lucy Kafanov, Robert Shackelford and Andi Babineau contributed to this report.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mary_gilbert@aol.com", "name": "Mary Gilbert", "type": "author", {"uri": "2024-05-348453221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "03:59:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T03:59:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T03:23:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/weather/2024/05/07/tuesday-forecast-severe-thunderstorms-tornadoes-live-updates/73592554007/", "title": "4 tornadoes confirmed in Michigan as severe weather threatens Central US: Live updates", "body": "Four tornadoes swept through Michigan Tuesday as tens of millions of people across the Central United States braced for severe storms, damaging hail and powerful winds.\n\nA tornado watch - which indicates conditions are ripe for tornadoes to form - was issued by the National Weather Service for much of Indiana, western Ohio and southern Michigan at 5 p.m. The weather service confirmed four tornadoes in Michigan, injuring at least one person and damaging several buildings, including a FedEx facility in Portage that collapsed.\n\n\"A few tornadoes are likely with a couple intense tornadoes possible,\" the Storm Prediction Center warned. The watch will stay in effect until 8:00 p.m. CDT.\n\nOverall, much of the central and eastern United States remains at risk for severe thunderstorms Tuesday from Texas to Wyoming and as far east as Pennsylvania and the Carolinas, according to the Weather Prediction Center. More than 13 million people in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky were at \"enhanced risk\" of seeing storms capable of unleashing \"very large hail\" and strong tornadoes.\n\nScattered supercell thunderstorms were forecast to spread across southern and eastern Indiana into western Ohio into late Tuesday. Supercells are the least common type of thunderstorm and tend to produce severe weather, including damaging winds, large hail and sometimes tornadoes, according to the weather service.\n\nIn addition to Chicago and Indianapolis, other metro areas at greatest risk for severe weather on Tuesday included Cincinnati, Columbus and Louisville, the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nTuesday's foul weather comes a day after strong storms battered the Plains region on Monday, spinning up multiple tornadoes that killed at least one person, destroyed buildings and knocked out power to thousands of households.\n\nThe threat of severe weather is forecast to continue across the Ohio Valley and mid-South regions on Wednesday, the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nDevelopments:\n\n\u220e At 7 p.m., more than 50,000 customers were without electricity across the region that saw storms over the previous 24 hours, to the database maintained by USA TODAY. That included nearly 31,000 customers in Michigan and roughly 7,000 each in Missouri and Oklahoma. It did not include another 45,000 customers without electricity in Colorado after winds as high as 80-90 mph on Monday.\n\n\u220e The outages had improved in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri were more than 30,000 were without power earlier Tuesday afternoon, according to the database. Of the three states, Missouri, pummeled by storms overnight, had the most outages with more than 11,000.\n\n\u220e Windy conditions and lower humidity could also pose a risk for critical fire weather across southeast Colorado, the Texas/Oklahoma Panhandle region and much of New Mexico.\n\n\u220e Two school districts in northeastern Oklahoma, Bartlesville Public Schools and Barnsdall Public Schools, canceled classes on Tuesday citing power outages and road closures. Both communities were ravaged by a powerful tornado on Monday night.\n\n\u220e Oklahoma's governor, Kevin Stitt, will travel to Barnsdall Tuesday afternoon to survey the damage to the small town: \"Devastating images coming out of Barnsdall, OK, this morning,\" the governor posted on X. \"First responders spent the night executing search and rescue operations. Resources are being directed to the area to aid in recovery. I will travel to Barnsdall later this afternoon. Hold them in your prayers!\"\n\nTornadoes hit Oklahoma: 1 person dead, 7 injured, dozens of homes damaged\n\nOn Monday, at least 17 tornadoes were spotted across the Plains region, with the most damage occurring in Oklahoma where multiple people were injured and one person in Barnsdall, a small community about 40 miles north of Tulsa, was killed, KOTV reported.\n\nThe northeastern Oklahoma communities of Barnsdall and Bartlesville experienced a damaging tornado that caused injuries, with at least seven people injured in Barnsdall, CBS News Texas reported.\n\nOklahoma Highway Patrol reported around 30 to 40 homes were damaged in the Barnsdall area, which was also hit by a tornado on April 1, according to the state's Department of Emergency Management. Officials also reported a natural gas leak in Barnsdall.\n\nCrews from numerous jurisdictions responded to areas throughout northeast Oklahoma to assist with medical transport, traffic control and search and rescue operations. Other counties reported flash flooding and damaged structures. Oklahoma was hit with tornadoes just last week that devastated some parts of the state, leaving at least four dead and 100 injured.\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa has a crew on the ground doing damage assessments along the track of the Barnsdall tornado and expects to have a report available later Tuesday or Wednesday.\n\nSlew of tornadoes slam southwest Michigan Tuesday\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency in four counties after a slew of tornadoes barreled through the southwestern part of the state and left a trail of damage in its wake.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nTwo \"large and extremely dangerous\" tornadoes were confirmed in Michigan shortly after 6 p.m., the weather service said. One hit south of Kalamazoo near Portage, moving east, and the other was near Burlington, about 9 miles northwest of Coldwater moving northeast.\n\nA woman taking cover from the tornado in Portage was hit by debris as she got out of her car and her leg was broken, according to the weather service. Authorities also reported damaged and destroyed buildings.\n\nCity officials said Tuesday evening that two tornadoes were believed to have touched down in Portage, Michigan, causing severe damage to residential and commercial properties. The city said several people were displaced, multiple trees were down on roads, and there were reports of gas leaks.\n\nSt. Joseph County Undersheriff Jason Bingaman confirmed multiple places across the southwest Michigan county were damaged Tuesday, the site of another confirmed tornado.\n\n\"At the moment, we are focused on life safety missions using all available resources, then we will begin preliminary damage assessments,\" Bingaman said.\n\nThe weather service also issued tornado watches for southeast Michigan counties but said the chance of tornadoes slamming that part of the state was unlikely.\n\nThe National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has tracked 1,219 tornadoes in Michigan since 1950, killing 248 people and causing more than $1.2 billion in property damage. Eighteen twisters swept through the state in 2023 and caused two deaths, according to the NOAA.\n\nTornadoes hit other Plains states overnight\n\nSeveral states in the Plains region were hit with tornadoes including two each in Iowa, Kansas and South Dakota and one each in Missouri, Nebraska and Tennessee, according to preliminary information from the Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe storms developed Monday afternoon and through the evening after the National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center issued a series of dire warnings for severe weather in an area that stretched from Texas to the Dakotas.\n\nHow to be safe during a tornado warning\n\nWhile there's no such thing as guaranteed safety, the weather service says there are things people can do to increase their chances of {"uri": "8116676442", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:03:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:03:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T05:03:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/storms-battering-the-midwest-bring-tornadoes-hail-and-strong-winds/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "Storms battering the Midwest bring tornadoes, hail and strong winds", "body": "Debris is seen from a damaged FedEx facility after a tornado in Portage, Mich., Tuesday, May 7, 2024.\n\nBy ED WHITE, ALEXA ST. JOHN and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nDETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region that forecasters warned could stretch into Wednesday morning.\n\nTornadoes were spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. Portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.\n\nIn southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nThere were no serious injuries immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Bloomington provides street resurfacing update PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Suspect in Heartland college carjacking granted pretrial release Pitching talents of Pontiac's Henry Brummel attracting professional scouts\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nBefore Monday night's powerful tornado touched down, the National Weather Service had warned that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" north of Tulsa was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville, several splintered 2x4s were driven into the south side of the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the hotel's lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage on Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\n\"Oklahomans are resilient,\" Stitt said, \"and we're going to rebuild.\"\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nThe powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst-ever flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heat wave.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8117684606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:50:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:50:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:50:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/national/2024/05/08/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "DETROIT - Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck a Michigan city and surrounding area, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nSurvey teams planned to head out Wednesday to determine whether tornadoes struck locations in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, according to Jeff Craven, the meteorologist-in-charge in the weather service's Pittsburgh office.\n\nRadar indicated Hancock County, West Virginia, and in Jefferson County, Ohio, were hit by tornadoes, but teams will have to evaluate the damage to determine their rating, Craven said.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage and an adjacent community Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nKalamazoo County Sheriff Richard Fuller said more than a dozen mobile homes in Pavilion Township were \"totally destroyed.\" At least 16 people, he added, were injured there, though the injuries were not life-threatening.\n\n\"We found homes in the roadway,\" the sheriff said late Tuesday. \"We found homes in neighbors' homes. We found large trees in homes.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the buzz of chainsaws and the snap of tree limbs filled the air as cleanup began at a mobile home park.\n\n\"The clean-up efforts are tremendous. ... We're looking at homes throughout this community that are totally gone, they've been demolished,\" Fuller said in the light of day Wednesday at Pavilion Estates mobile home park.\n\nA home where seven people were living \"is totally on its top,\" he said. \"They were able to self-rescue and get somewhere safe and came back today.\"\n\nPavilion Township is adjacent to Portage and about 137 miles (220 kilometers) west of Detroit.\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield, Beatrice Dupuy and Alexa St. John.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8117368481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:30:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:30:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:29:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/news/state-and-regional/illinois/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_dc2ffe99-48ab-51c7-bfd7-7893134b2b41.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "Debris and damage from powerful storms are seen, Tuesday, May 7, 2024 in Barnsdall, Okla. A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through the small Oklahoma town.\n\nBy ED WHITE, ALEXA ST. JOHN and SEAN MURPHY - Associated Press\n\nDETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nThe tornadoes were first spotted after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nPeople are also reading... Carnival to return to Eastland Mall this week Police clear scene on West Washington Street Bloomington man gets 75-year prison sentence in 2023 murder at Victory Church 7 arrested on trespassing charges at ISU following week of protests Classical Christian school to open in Normal this fall Flick Fact: The average age of a State Farm employee? Bloomington provides street resurfacing update WJBC mourns loss of former radio host Scott Laughlin Ferrero's first North American chocolate processing facility opens in Bloomington Bloomington police give Stevenson Elementary 'all-clear' after dismissal delayed for gunfire reports Ex-Unit 5 teacher sentenced on reduced charges of trespassing in Decatur, assault in Nashville Invasive species of tick confirmed in Central Illinois PATH to lay off dozens in Bloomington after losing state 988 grant Flick Fact: The top public high school in Illinois outside of Chicago? Rivian receives $827M state incentive package to expand operations in Normal\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. {"uri": "8116464302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "01:11:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T01:11:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T01:11:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/05/07/breaking-news/nearly-13m-in-midwest-brace-for-more-storms-after-tornado-kills-1/", "title": "Nearly 13M in Midwest brace for more storms after tornado kills 1 | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Scenes of destruction in Barnsdall, Okla., a day after a tornado hit it and nearby towns. Severe storms moved through the Midwest on Tuesday, bringing heavy rain and strong winds a day after tornadoes in the southern Plains killed at least one person and damaged dozens of homes.\n\nSevere storms moved through the Midwest on Tuesday, bringing heavy rain and strong winds a day after tornadoes in the southern Plains killed at least one person and damaged dozens of homes.\n\nAbout 13.5 million people in parts of Indiana, northern Kentucky and western Ohio were warned about an enhanced risk for severe thunderstorms through Tuesday evening, with the possibility of strong tornadoes and large hail, according to the Storm Prediction Center of the National Weather Service.\n\nThe roughly 60,000-square-mile area could also experience frequent lightning and strong wind gusts, according to the Weather Service.\n\nAs storms moved through the region Tuesday afternoon, the Weather Service issued a string of tornado warnings in cities across Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana and Michigan.\n\nA larger section of the Midwest, encompassing nearly 16 million people across portions of Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee, was facing a slight risk of severe weather Tuesday.\n\nAaron Updike, a meteorologist for the service in Indianapolis, one of the cities under an enhanced risk, said severe weather would move into the region in the morning and fade away shortly thereafter.\n\n\"We're going to get some redevelopment this afternoon and evening,\" he said. \"And that is where our primary focus is.\"\n\nThe Weather Service also warned that storms passing over the region would produce heavy rain that may create some localized areas of flash flooding. Urban areas, roads, small streams and low-lying areas were most vulnerable, meteorologists said.\n\nAt least 15 tornadoes were reported to have struck parts of the Plains on Monday night. One tornado that was up to 2 miles wide ripped through Barnsdall, Oklahoma, a city about 40 miles northwest of Tulsa, killing one person, an Osage County official said.\n\nIn the predawn hours, it was difficult to assess the damage caused by the tornado, but one Osage County official said it had leveled about one-third of the small city, which has a population of about 1,000, and caused multiple injuries. The Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported that up to 40 homes in the town had been damaged.\n\nThe tornado also lifted the roof off a nursing home in Barnsdall, though all residents were accounted for with no injuries or deaths, officials said.\n\nRescuers were going through debris Tuesday with a fine-toothed comb, said Mayor Johnny Kelley. One person was reported missing, he said.\n\n\"We are going through the debris very thoroughly,\" Kelley said at a news conference Tuesday.\n\nConsidering the widespread destruction, it was \"shocking\" there were so few casualties, he said: \"The devastation is pretty substantial.\"\n\nThe tornado also caused power outages in Missouri, Arkansas and Oklahoma. But by early Tuesday, power had been restored to all but about 10,000 customers in Oklahoma, according PowerOutage.us, which aggregates utilities information across the U.S.\n\nIn Bartlesville, Oklahoma, about 45 miles north of Tulsa, city officials said that emergency responders had rescued a number of trapped people at a Hampton Inn and were recovering downed power lines early Tuesday. They said minor injuries had been reported.\n\nRescue operations were also ongoing at the Osage Nation Reservation, where officials warned residents to stay clear of the roadways and damaged areas.", {"uri": "8116340250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "22:37:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T22:37:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:33:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/prayers-tornado-left-path-destruction-213615454.html", "title": "'We need prayers': A tornado left a path of destruction and death in Barnsdall, Oklahoma", "body": "BARNSDALL -- Along State Highway 123, just outside of town, a house owned by Tim and Joy King was blown about 20 yards off its foundation.\n\nJoy King, 56, wearing a pink tie-dye shirt that said \"blessed,\" was surveying the damage done to her property with her husband, Tim, and their dog, Wendy. King said she took cover in the home's cellar while her husband was at work at a nearby plant.\n\nAs the tornado came through, the cellar door blew open and began to fill with water up to her ankles. Insulation began blowing around her.\n\n\"I thought, 'Lord, that's my house.'\"\n\nThe Kings' home was just one of dozens that were damaged or destroyed in the at least EF3 deadly tornado that tore through the small city of Barnsdall in Osage County, before leaving destruction in Bartlesville to the northeast.\n\nThe devastating storm left at least one person dead in Barnsdall, and at least one person was still missing Tuesday afternoon in the city of about 1,400, according to the Osage County Sheriff's Office.\n\nThe law enforcement agency requested the public's help via a social media post in locating Wayne Hogue, who they say went missing after the tornado.\n\nIt's the second time Barnsdall was affected by a tornado this year, after another tornado damaged homes on April 1.\n\n\"It's very tough,\" Mayor Johnny Kelley told reporters Tuesday. \"The toughest thing on me as the mayor is, this is a small community. I know 75 to 80% of the people in this town. The individual that we lost, I knew them very well.\"\n\nBy the time the storm reached Bartlesville, the tornado had merged with a front-line storm and was weakened. Oklahoma state Rep. Judd Strom, R-Bartlesville, told the Bartlesville Examiner-Enterprise that local emergency management had been preparing for an EF4 tornado to rip across the city.\n\nAt least five tornadoes have been confirmed in Oklahoma from Monday night's storms, including the Barnsdall tornado and four in the National Weather Service's Norman forecast area -- those tornadoes were in or near the towns of Helena, Okeene, Bison and Covington. Damage survey teams will determine if more are to be added to that list.\n\nMeteorologist Joe Sellers, who works with the weather service's Tulsa office, said a survey of the damage in Osage County would \"take a while.\"\n\nNatasha Coday, 39, the Kings' daughter, looked up at her parent's house in Barnsdall and pointed to where it had been forced from its foundation.\n\n\"It was right here,\" she said. \"That tornado just pushed it up and moved it over there.\"\n\nCoday was in Bartlesville during the storm and stayed on the phone with her mother as the tornado moved through Barnsdall.\n\n\"God really, really took care of them last night,\" she said. The Kings' pontoon had blown into the back of the property, a pickup had been tossed upside down and part of their camper was thrown into a tree.\n\nKing said she swore more than a month ago she'd never go back in the cellar, after getting trapped in it during the April 1 tornado that went through Barnsdall. But when the storm came through Monday night, King said she felt she \"needed to\" get back in.\n\nAmid all the destruction, a photo album of Joy and Tim King's wedding was saved.\n\nDuring an initial search Monday night after the tornado, about 25 people were rescued, including children. A secondary search took place Tuesday morning for some people still unaccounted for.\n\nSeven or eight people were injured, including one firefighter who was experiencing chest pains, Kelley said.\n\n\"We're worried about our neighbors and our friends that have lost loved ones,\" Kelley said. \"To me, material things are material. We can replace them. The loss of life is forever.\"\n\nWhen asked what the community needs at this time, Kelley answered, \"we need prayers.\"\n\nCarl Kelley, 55, rode out the storm in a closet with his mother, 80. Two mounted deer heads were lying in the yard as he tried to unlock his gun safe Tuesday morning.\n\nThe tornado shredded his house with debris thrown across the yard and in the trees. The trees were either bent or knocked over, and power lines knocked down around the property.\n\n\"I didn't think it was that bad until I looked up and didn't see the roof,\" he said.\n\nIn its wake, the tornado left several Bartlesville streets closed Tuesday due to downed power lines and fallen trees, said City Manager Mike Bailey and Washington County Emergency Management Director Kary Cox.\n\nThe storm caused significant structural damage to buildings, utilities and trees, especially in southwest Bartlesville near the Circle Mountain area and northeast sections along U.S. 75 and Tuxedo, impacting homes and businesses.\n\nDespite the extensive damage, no fatalities or serious injuries have been reported.\n\nEmergency response teams, including police, fire and street departments, were deployed after the storm struck.\n\nSeveral rescues, including guests trapped at the Hampton Inn on N U.S. 75, were successfully conducted by the combined efforts of Bartlesville, Dewey and Copan fire departments.\n\nKelley, the Barnsdall mayor, said he believes the fatality count was low thanks to his community staying \"weather aware,\" as the day was predicted to see numerous severe storms and a potential tornado outbreak.\n\n\"I attribute that to people paying attention to the weather and the warnings,\" Kelley said. \"And when the sirens were blowing and the warnings were given out over their cellphones and over their TVs, that they took cover and did what they needed to do to keep safe.\"\n\nA portion of central and northern Oklahoma was given the rare \"high\" risk categorization for severe storms and multiple strong tornadoes by the weather service's Storm Prediction Center. So far, the number of tornadoes is much lower than the outbreak of April 27 when 30 tornadoes were confirmed in Oklahoma.\n\nDuring that outbreak, the office of the chief medical examiner reported four storm-related fatalities: two in Holdenville while in a mobile home, one on Interstate 35 near Marietta while in a vehicle and one fatality in Sulphur in a business.\n\nThompson said while some may feel Monday's event did not live up to the risk level warned, it's all \"a matter of perception.\"\n\nContributing: Alexia Aston, The Oklahoman", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", Forecasters issue warning for rare powerful storm, 3.4 million people at risk", "body": "The greatest risk of bad weather can be seen in central Oklahoma and southern Kansas including areas Sulphur and Holdenville.\n\nThe US forecasters have warned the central United States of rare high-risk powerful storms that may include long-track tornadoes, hurricane-force winds and baseball-sized hail. The greatest risk of bad weather can be seen in central Oklahoma and southern Kansas including areas Sulphur and Holdenville.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service, more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far north Texas, face the most severe threat of tornadoes.\n\nOklahoma braces for storm\n\nNearly 10 million individuals reside in areas potentially affected by severe weather, as indicated by the National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center. Schools and colleges statewide, including the University of Oklahoma and Oklahoma City Public Schools, closed early and cancelled afternoon and evening activities.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, active since last weekend's fatal storms, remains engaged, and the state agencies were asked by the state's commissioner of public safety to let most of their workers across Oklahoma leave early on Monday.\n\nBill Bunting, the Storm Prediction Center's deputy director, emphasised the rarity and seriousness of the high-risk designation, urging extreme caution. The last such alert was issued on March 31, 2023, coinciding with severe storms across several states. Anticipated cities under threat include Kansas City, Missouri, and Lincoln, Nebraska, with storm intensity expected to escalate rapidly, particularly in western Oklahoma and south-central Kansas, potentially spawning dangerous tornadoes.\n\nAccording to meteorologist Porter, supercell storms with winds exceeding 80 mph pose significant risks. Victor Gensini, a meteorology professor, warned that the threat would persist into the evening and overnight hours, challenging forecasting and response efforts.\n\nThe upcoming week forecasts continued storminess, with the eastern US and the South, including populous areas like Indianapolis and Memphis, likely to face severe weather, affecting over 21 million people. {"uri": "8115360405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "10:35:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T10:35:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T10:35:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/b8def43f7b0402d12911573ea5b4233b/tornado-causes-extensive-damage-oklahoma-town-and-1-death", "title": "Tornado causes extensive damage to Oklahoma town and 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night.\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and the state Department of Health reported a nursing home was damaged and patients were being evacuated. A natural gas leak and numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, and Colleen Slevin in Denver contributed to this report.\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. AP is solely responsible for all content. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center cited 17 reports of tornadoes from Monday evening through early Tuesday in the central part of the United States. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee. A tornado emergency was issued for Union City -- marking the first tornado emergency for the state on record, going back to 1999.\n\nThe National Weather Service warned there was a \"confirmed large and destructive tornado\" over Union City at 6:11 p.m. ET Tuesday.\n\nThe mayor of Portage, Michigan, near Kalamazoo, said her city suffered \"extensive damage to both residential and commercial properties\" after two tornadoes went through the area. Power was down on Tuesday night in the area, with downed trees and wires hindering repairs, she said.\n\nPhotos showed major damage to a FedEx facility in Portage. The company's facility there sustained heavy damage, with at least 50 people inside, officials said. There were no reports of serious injuries, according to authorities.\n\nEarlier on Tuesday evening, Whitmer advised people to pay attention to the weather alerts.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those affected by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan. Emergency teams are on the ground and working to assist Michiganders. I encourage everyone to continue monitoring severe weather alerts and follow the advice of emergency officials,\" she said in a statement on X.\n\nAfter more than a dozen tornadoes were reported in the Plains overnight into Tuesday, the tornado threat moved into Ohio Valley and parts of the southern Great Lakes Tuesday afternoon and evening. Some 35 million Americans are in the storm zone, from Chicago to Nashville, Tennessee.\n\nA tornado watch was issued for parts of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Kentucky into Tuesday night. A few tornadoes, damaging gusts up to 70 mph and baseball-sized hail are likely.\n\nKentucky Gov. Andy Beshear urged residents to prepare for the severe weather -- including \"potentially significant tornadoes,\" flooding, hail and high winds -- expected to hit much of the state over the next few days.\n\n\"We have been through all of those and we have seen how deadly they can be,\" Beshear said during a press briefing Tuesday. \"So we need everyone to take action now by making a plan to keep yourself and your family safe.\"\n\nThe latest tornado threat comes as at least 20 tornadoes were reported in seven states overnight into Tuesday.\n\nThe twisters were reported in Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Tennessee.\n\nOne of the hardest-hit areas in the storm was Barnsdall and Bartlesville, Oklahoma, north of Tulsa. Kevin Stitt said.\n\nApproximately 25 people were rescued following an initial search, Kelley said. One person remains unaccounted for as another search effort got underway Tuesday, he said.\n\nThe missing man was in his trailer home talking to his son on the phone just minutes before the tornado came through, according to Stitt. Police K-9 units are involved in the search, he said.\n\n\"We're just praying a miracle happens,\" Stitt told reporters during a press briefing Tuesday evening.\n\nStitt has declared a state of emergency for several counties in the state due to the severe weather.\n\nThe destructive tornado was the second to hit Barnsdall in recent weeks.\n\n\"It's a devastating blow to the people in the {"uri": "2024-05-348040335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:51:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.aol.com/severe-storms-threaten-midwest-deadly-115828510.html", "title": "Severe weather threatens central US after deadly storms hit Oklahoma: Live updates", "body": "Severe weather threatens central US after deadly storms hit Oklahoma: Live updatesAnthony Robledo, Christopher Cann and Doyle Rice, USA TODAYUpdated May 7, 2024 at 10:21 PM\n\nMore violent weather is forecast for Wednesday, focusing on the Ohio Valley and Mid-South regions, after a round of severe weather pounded the Midwest on Tuesday, targeting tens of millions of people with tornadoes, large hail and strong winds.\n\nOverall, much of the central and eastern United States was at risk of severe thunderstorms Tuesday from Texas to Wyoming and as far east as Pennsylvania and the Carolinas, according to the Weather Prediction Center. More than 12 million people in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky were at \"enhanced risk\" of storms capable of unleashing \"very large hail\" and strong tornadoes.\n\nMetro areas at greatest risk for severe weather on Tuesday included Indianapolis, Cincinnati, Columbus, and Louisville, the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nTuesday's foul weather came a day after strong storms battered the Plains region on Monday, spinning up multiple tornadoes that killed at least one person, destroyed buildings and knocked out power to thousands of households.\n\nThe threat for severe weather is forecast to continue across the Ohio Valley and mid-South regions on Wednesday, the Storm Prediction Center said.\n\nDevelopments:\n\n\u220e More than 30,000 people across Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri were without power Tuesday morning, according to a database maintained by USA TODAY. Of the three states, Missouri, which was pummeled by storms overnight, had the most outages with over 11,000.\n\n\u220e Windy conditions and lower humidity could also pose a risk for critical fire weather across southeast Colorado, the Texas/Oklahoma Panhandle region and much of New Mexico.\n\n\u220e Two school districts in northeastern Oklahoma, Bartlesville Public Schools and Barnsdall Public Schools, canceled classes on Tuesday citing power outages and road closures. Both communities were ravaged Monday night by a powerful tornado.\n\n\u220e Oklahoma governor Kevin Stitt will travel to Barnsdall Tuesday afternoon to survey the damage to the small town: \"Devastating images coming out of Barnsdall, OK, this morning,\" the governor posted on X. \"First responders spent the night executing search and rescue operations. Resources are being directed to the area to aid in recovery. I will travel to Barnsdall later this afternoon. Hold them in your prayers!\"\n\nTornadoes hit Oklahoma: 1 person dead, 7 injured, dozens of homes damaged\n\nOn Monday, at least 17 tornadoes were spotted across the Plains region, with the most damage occurring in Oklahoma where multiple people were injured and one person in Barnsdall, a small community about 40 miles north of Tulsa, was killed, KOTV reported.\n\nThe northeastern Oklahoma communities of Barnsdall and Bartlesville experienced a damaging tornado that caused injuries, with at least seven people injured in Barnsdall, CBS News Texas reported.\n\nOklahoma Highway Patrol reported around 30-40 homes were damaged in the Barnsdall area, which was also hit by a tornado on April 1, according to the state's Department of Emergency Management. Officials also reported a natural gas leak in Barnsdall.\n\nCrews from the numerous jurisdictions responded to areas throughout northeast Oklahoma to assist with medical transport, traffic control and search and rescue operations. Other counties reported flash flooding and damaged structures. Oklahoma just last week was hit with tornadoes that devastated some parts of the state, leaving at least four dead and 100 injured.\n\nTornadoes hit other Plains states overnight\n\nSeveral states in the Plains region were hit with tornadoes including two each in Iowa, Kansas and South Dakota and one each in Missouri, Nebraska and Tennessee, according to preliminary information from the Storm Prediction Center.\n\nThe storms developed Monday afternoon and through the evening after the National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center issued a series of dire warnings for severe weather in an area that stretched from Texas to the Dakotas.\n\nHow to be safe during a tornado warning\n\nWhile there's no such thing as guaranteed safety, the weather service says there are things people can do to increase their chances of surviving a deadly tornado.\n\nProtect yourself from flying or falling debris, the single biggest life-threatening hazard.\n\nSeek shelter in the closest, safest interior or underground room.\n\nAlways avoid windows. Don't go to the windows or doors to look outside.\n\nCover yourself with thick protective coverings, such as a mattress, sleeping bags and thick blankets or other protective coverings.\n\nWear a helmet if you have one to protect your head from debris.\n\nUS weather watches and warnings\n\nNational weather radar\n\nContributing: Dinah Voyles Pulver, USA TODAY; Jana Hayes, Dale Denwalt and They said no one had been injured, but that residents had to be relocated because of a gas leak.\n\nOfficials said on Tuesday that emergency crews were responding in the Barnsdall area, and asked people to stay off the roads to allow first responders to reach affected areas.\n\nParts of Oklahoma were reported to have been without power after several power lines were downed.\n\nStorm warnings were still in effect in parts of the state, with a \"squall line\" of damaging thunderstorms expected to stretch from central Iowa to around Oklahoma City, the Washington Post said.\n\nSeveral tornado watches were still in effect across other parts of the central U.S. early on Tuesday, including parts of Kansas, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois and Iowa.\n\nThese tornadoes come just a week after
