{"uri": "8115506160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:03:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:03:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:03:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/second-tornado-in-5-weeks-damages-oklahoma-town-and-causes-1-death-as-powerful-storms/article_1fe9f943-1d03-559a-ac9a-dcc0ea930525.html", "title": "Second tornado in 5 weeks damages Oklahoma town and causes 1 death as powerful storms hit central US", "body": "OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) -- A tornado destroyed homes, forced the evacuation of a nursing home and toppled trees and power lines when it roared through a small Oklahoma town, one of several twisters that erupted in the central United States amid a series of powerful storms that stretched into Tuesday. At least one death was reported.\n\nThe tornado ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, on Monday night. It was the second tornado to hit the town in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles in Barnsdall.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nAt least 30 to 40 homes in the Barnsdall area were damaged Monday night, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol reported, and a nursing home said it evacuated residents because a gas leak that could not be turned off due to storm damage. Numerous road closings due to debris also were reported, according to Osage County Emergency Management.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We've got one confirmed fatality and multiple injuries,\" Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told KOKI-TV.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home posted online that all residents were accounted for with no injuries. They were being transported to other facilities. It asked families to bear with them \"as it is chaos in town ... Please pray for us.\"\n\nDamage also was reported in Bartlesville, about 20 miles northeast.\n\n\"We did take a direct hit from a tornado\" in the city, said Kary Fox of the Washington County Emergency Management. \"Please stay off the roadways. Stay out of those damaged areas. We're having a lot of difficulty getting in to do assessments to check on people, to see if they've got any injuries because of the traffic congestion.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Center warned of an enhanced risk of severe thunderstorms across the Ohio Valley on Tuesday with a possibility of few, potentially strong, tornadoes, hail and severe, damaging winds.\n\nThe main threat was shifting east into on Tuesday, said Roger Edwards, lead forecaster with the center, though it is not as intense a threat as on Monday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe weather service in Tulsa had warned Monday evening that \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" was headed toward Barnsdall, with wind gusts up to 70 mph (112 kph). Meteorologist Brad McGavock said information on the tornado's size and how far it traveled wasn't immediately available Monday night.\n\nThe storms began earlier Monday with gusty winds and rain. But after dark, tornadoes were spotted skirting northern Oklahoma. At one point in the evening, a storm in the small town of Covington had \"produced tornadoes off and on for over an hour,\" the National Weather Service said. Throughout the area, wind farm turbines spun rapidly in the wind and blinding rain.\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. He said the entire ground-level room is built with reinforced concrete walls.\n\nOklahoma and Kansas had been under a high-risk weather warning Monday. The last time such a warning was issued was March 31, 2023, when a massive storm system tore through parts of the South and Midwest including Arkansas, Illinois and rural Indiana.\n\nThe entire week is looking stormy across the U.S. The eastern U.S. and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati, cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nMeanwhile, floodwaters in the Houston area began receding Monday after days of heavy rain in southeastern Texas left neighborhoods flooded and led to hundreds of high-water rescues.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nSt. John reported from Detroit and Salter from O'Fallon, Missouri. Associated Press writers Rio Yamat in Las Vegas, Heather Hollingsworth in Mission, Kansas, Colleen Slevin in Denver, Kathy McCormack in Concord, New Hampshire, and Sarah Brumfield in Silver Spring, Maryland, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAlexa St. John is an Associated Press climate solutions reporter. Follow her on X: @alexa_stjohn. Reach her at ast.john@ap.org.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nThere were no serious injuries immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the small 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks - a twister on April 1 with maximum wind {"uri": "2024-05-348332660", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "00:09:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T00:09:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T22:25:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.aol.com/1-dead-oklahoma-tornadoes-millions-132158086.html", "title": "1 dead after Oklahoma tornadoes as millions in the Midwest face a strong tornado threat", "body": "1 dead after Oklahoma tornadoes as millions in the Midwest face a strong tornado threatMary Gilbert, CNNMay 8, 2024 at 12:25 AM\n\nDestructive storms roared through the Plains Monday, unloading at least one deadly tornado, giant hail and hurricane-force wind gusts. As some communities pick up the pieces, others were preparing Tuesday for the threat of strong twisters in the Midwest.\n\n* One dead, several injured: At least one person is dead and several others are injured after a tornado tore through Oklahoma's Osage and Washington counties Monday night, Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden said in an on-air interview with CNN affiliate KOKI. Extensive damage occurred to dozens of homes between Barnsdall and Bartlesville. A search was ongoing in Barnsdall Tuesday for \"one or two\" people still unaccounted for, the town's mayor Johnny Kelley said at a news conference.\n\n* Tornado damage in at least two other states: A tornado caused \"considerable damage\" in Sullivan, Missouri, late Monday night according to storm reports. The extent of the damage is unclear, but images from the scene showed buildings filleted by the twister. Another tornado tore through parts of DeKalb County, Tennessee, and damaged at least a dozen homes in the Smithville area early Monday afternoon, officials told CNN.\n\n* More than 200 storm reports: There were 244 storm reports Monday, including 17 tornado reports, according to the Storm Prediction Center. Hail the size of softballs slammed down in Kansas while baseball-sized hail pummeled Oklahoma. Wind gusts of 70 mph or greater were recorded in Nebraska and Kansas while an 82-mph wind gust occurred near Chester, Oklahoma.\n\n* Rare high risk issued: Monday marked the first high - Level 5 of 5 - risk issued for the US by the Storm Prediction Center in more than a year. It was the first time in nearly five years Oklahoma was under such an extreme risk and the first time in nearly seven years in Kansas.\n\n* More storms to come: Level 3 of 5 risks for severe thunderstorms are in place for parts of the US on Tuesday and Wednesday, with millions at risk of damaging wind gusts, hail and tornadoes.\n\nTown hit by tornado for the second time in five weeks\n\nMonday night's triggered a tornado emergency for Barnsdall, Oklahoma, but residents here were all too familiar with the situation. It was the second damaging tornado in just over a month to hit the town, which was struck by an EF1 on April 1.\n\nUnder the cover of darkness Monday night, the large and destructive tornado barreled through the town.\n\nDorothy Aultz and her son Carl Kelley were at Dorothy's Barnsdall home when the tornado hit. Dorothy is elderly and receiving hospice care, Carl told CNN, so he went to his mother's home to protect her during the storm.\n\nWith a tornado on the way and no basement to shelter in, Carl had to improvise. He placed blankets on the bathroom floor, placed Dorothy on them and laid on top of her to protect her from debris.\n\nThe tornado tore through the home and destroyed most of it, but the bathroom held strong. Both mother and son made through the experience unscathed and were rescued from the rubble.\n\nThey were among the roughly two dozen people rescued from their damaged or destroyed homes Monday night, Kelley, the city's mayor, said in a news conference Tuesday.\n\nThe full extent of the tornado's destruction in Barnsdall didn't become clear until the sun rose Tuesday. Much of the town has \"significant damage;\" a nursing home was damaged and evacuated; and several homes were \"completely leveled,\" Kelley said.\n\nBut it's the loss of a man Kelley knew well in this close-knit community of 1,400 that will stick with him, he said.\n\n\"To me, the material things are material, you can replace them,\" Kelley said. \"The loss of life, it's something that's forever.\"\n\nTornado threat shifts to Midwest, Tennessee Valley Tuesday\n\nStrong storms shifted east on Tuesday and have ushered in a renewed threat of damaging wind gusts, large hail and tornadoes.\n\nSevere thunderstorms got underway Tuesday afternoon in parts of Illinois but will expand across much of the Midwest and Tennessee Valley through the evening.\n\nNearly 13 million people here are at risk of a few strong tornadoes of at least EF2 strength. The Level 3 of 5 risk area includes large portions of Indiana, including Indianapolis; Kentucky, including Louisville; and Ohio, including Columbus.\n\nDamaging winds and hail are possible outside of the highest risk area across a huge portion of the eastern US.\n\nMillions are at risk of damaging storms once again on Wednesday, including areas hard-hit by Monday's storms.\n\nAn expansive Level 3 of 5 risk of severe thunderstorms is in place from northeastern Texas and eastern Oklahoma to much of Kentucky and Tennessee. Damaging wind gusts, hail bigger than baseballs and tornadoes are all possible within Wednesday's storms.\n\nSome strong tornadoes are possible, mainly from Missouri through central Kentucky and northern Tennessee. St. Louis and Nashville are just two cities at risk of powerful tornadoes.\n\nTorrential rainfall may also occur within any storm Wednesday and trigger flash flooding. A Level 2 of 4 risk of excessive rainfall is in place for a large portion of the Tennessee and Ohio valleys, according to the Weather Prediction Center. Rainfall rates could approach 1 to 2 inches per hour in the heaviest storms.\n\nCNN's Joe Sutton, Lucy Kafanov, Robert Shackelford and Andi Babineau contributed to this report.\n\nFor more CNN news {"uri": "8115635006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "13:19:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T13:19:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T13:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/tornado-hits-oklahoma-hotel-video-1897870", "title": "Video shows \"insane\" moment tornado hits Oklahoma hotel", "body": "Two men at a Hampton Inn in Oklahoma filmed the \"insane\" moment a tornado slammed into their hotel on Monday night.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a tornado warning for Bartlesville, Oklahoma, on Monday night. The warning came after the NWS issued a high-risk severe weather outlook, the highest possible level of alert, for Oklahoma and Kansas earlier in the day as a storm system threatened tornadoes, strong winds and grapefruit-sized hail.\n\nThe tornado hit Bartlesville, Oklahoma in the nighttime hours -- one of the most dangerous times for tornadoes since people can't see its arrival.\n\nInstead of taking shelter, two men at the Hampton Inn stood outside the hotel watching the storm's approach before darting inside at the last minute.\n\n\"Terrifying footage shows the moment as a large damaging tornado prompted by a tornado emergency hit the Hampton Inn causing major damage to the town #Bartlesville | #Oklahoma,\" social media account Raws Alerts posted on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Watch as new footage shows the terrifying moment captured by people inside Hampton Inn as it was being annihilated by a massive tornado as The National Weather Service issued a tornado emergency for Bartlesville, Oklahoma, due to a large confirmed violent tornado passing through the town, resulting major damages to [multiple] buildings and home along with one fatality.\"\n\nIn the video, the men are standing outside as tornado sirens wail around them. High winds are tearing through the area. Then, upon realizing they are about to get hit, the footage becomes chaotic as they sprint inside to take shelter. They hurry behind what appears to be a hotel desk as the tornado rips through the building.\n\nAccording to the Raws Alerts post, the tornado ripped off the hotel's roof and sent it flying into a nursing home. No injuries were reported.\n\nNWS meteorologist Bart Haake told Newsweek that meteorologists will know the tornado's severity rating after damage assessment later on Tuesday. However, he advised people against filming the storm's approach and reminded them to seek safety before a severe storm arrives.\n\n\"That's not even just tornados, large hail can be deadly,\" he said. \"It's really best to get into a place of safety before the danger is about to strike.\"\n\nThe same tornado that hit Bartlesville allegedly tore through nearby Barnsdall, leaving behind a slew of damage.\n\n\"Aerial views of the devastation in Barnsdall, OK after a tornado tore through the community leaving at least one confirmed death,\" The Weather Channel reporter Charles Peek posted on X with a video of multiple police lights flashing near the damage.\n\nFox 25 showed footage of the devastation on Tuesday morning. In the report, piles of debris and rubble were scattered around Barnsdall.\n\n\"DAYLIGHT IMAGES FROM BARNSDALL With the sun up, we're getting a better look at the damage in the town of Barnsdall. This is one of the worst tornado seasons we've had in years. The damage is so widespread,\" Fox 25 anchor Wayne Stafford posted.\n\nHaake told Newsweek that there are no threats for the Tulsa, Oklahoma, area, which includes Barnsdall and Bartlesville, on {"uri": "8115569498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "12:40:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T12:40:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T12:39:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.foxweather.com/weather-news/barnsdall-oklahoma-tornado-damage-monday", "title": "1 dead after catastrophic tornado levels Barnsdall, Oklahoma: 'Total destruction'", "body": "BARNSDALL, Okla. - One person has died after a devastating tornado destroyed homes and toppled power lines as it moved through a small town northeast of Oklahoma City on Monday evening.\n\nThe National Weather Service (NWS) reports that Barnsdall, a town of about 1,000 people located a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, was leveled about 10 p.m. by a tornado that rated at least EF-3 strength on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.\n\nThe nearby town of Bartlesville also suffered severe damage from the same tornado. Multiple injuries are reported, but the exact number has yet to be confirmed. Damage surveys will continue on Tuesday.\n\nDEADLY TORNADO RIPS THROUGH BARNSDALL, OKLAHOMA, AS SEVERE WEATHER PRODUCES CATASTROPHIC DAMAGE IN CENTRAL US\n\nA Tornado Emergency, the most dire of tornado alerts, was issued for Osage County in Oklahoma on Monday evening as the storm approached. The NWS referred to a \"large and destructive tornado\" moving towards Barnsdall and causing catastrophic damage.\n\nOsage County Emergency Management Director Jerry Roberts told FOX Weather that Oklahoma Task Force 1 Tulsa, along with the Oklahoma Highway Patrol and crews from numerous jurisdictions, arrived in Barnsdall overnight to aid in the search for survivors.\n\n\"Right now, we have a big area of total destruction,\" Roberts adds.\n\nAccording to the Oklahoma Highway Patrol, as many as 40 homes were damaged in the Barnsdall area. Multiple reports of natural gas leaks and debris in roadways led to the closure of numerous roads.\n\nThe Oklahoma State Department of Health said the town's nursing home was damaged, and patients were evacuated to nearby facilities. No nursing home patients suffered injuries requiring hospital care, state officials said.\n\nThe Tornado Emergency for Barnsdall was just the second one ever issued by the NWS in Tulsa, and one of 13 Tornado Warnings issued by that office on Monday. They left the city of 50,000 people with heavy damage, littering streets with debris of buildings, downed power lines and trees.\n\nAt one point, downed power lines trapped an estimated 50 people inside a FedEx facility, local authorities said as first responders tried to get them out.\n\nFedEx spokesperson Shannon Davis confirmed late on Monday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for\".\n\nMichigan governor Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for Kalamazoo and neighbouring areas which were lashed by strong storms and hail.\n\nMore than 18,000 people were left without power across Kalamazoo county, PowerOutages said.\n\nThe National Weather Service's Storm Prediction Centre documented over 12 tornado sightings spanning from Monday evening to early Tuesday across the central region of the US.\n\nAt least eight tornadoes were reported in Oklahoma and there were sightings in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee as well.\n\nThe storms are expected to continue for a third day with cities in Ohio and Kentucky, including Columbus, Cincinnati and Louisville, expected to face the risk of worsening weather conditions until Wednesday.\n\nA tornado in Oklahoma levelled a third of a small city of 1,000 people and caused multiple injuries. Forecasters had warned of \"a large and life-threatening tornado\" that was headed toward Barnsdall and the nearby town of Bartlesville.\n\nThe Oklahoma Highway Patrol said that up to 40 homes in the town had been damaged.\n\nOne person was killed in Barnsdall and another was missing after Monday's twister, mayor Johnny Kelley said. {"uri": "8117452753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:23:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:23:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:20:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/severe-storms-batter-the-midwest-including-reported-tornadoes-that-shredded-a-fedex-facility/article_26f2e9db-ec59-5b99-b55f-a049101e6b9f.html", "title": "Severe storms batter the Midwest, including reported tornadoes that shredded a FedEx facility", "body": "DETROIT (AP) -- Severe storms barreled through the Midwest early Wednesday, a day after two reported tornadoes struck one Michigan city and destroyed homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility.\n\nTornadoes were first reported after dark Tuesday in parts of Michigan, Indiana and Ohio, while portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service. The storms came a day after a deadly twister ripped through an Oklahoma town.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nAs the storms raged on in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, the National Weather Service in Pittsburgh warned that a tornado in northeastern Ohio could cross into Pennsylvania. Parts of West Virginia were also under a tornado warning.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHancock County Schools in West Virginia closed schools Wednesday because of \"extensive overnight weather issues\" in the county. News outlets reported damaged buildings and power outages.\n\nHours earlier in southwestern Michigan, two reported tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo on Tuesday night, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.\n\nNo serious injuries were immediately reported, but city officials said in a news release that the twisters knocked out power to more than 20,000 people. Most of them would be without power until late Wednesday, city officials said.\n\nAt one point, about 50 people were trapped inside the FedEx facility because of downed power lines. But company spokesperson Shannon Davis said late Tuesday that \"all team members are safe and accounted for.\"\n\nMore than 30,000 customers were without power in Michigan early Wednesday, and an additional 10,000 in Ohio, according to PowerOutage.us.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMichigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer declared a state of emergency for four counties.\n\n\"My heart goes out to all those impacted by tonight's severe weather in southwest Michigan,\" Whitmer said in a message on social media. \"State and local emergency teams are on the ground and working together to assist Michiganders.\"\n\nNational Weather Service crews were working Wednesday to survey storm damage in several counties in Michigan's southwest Lower Peninsula to determine whether tornadoes touched down in those areas, including the two reported Tuesday night in the city of Portage, said meteorologist Mike Sutton with the weather service's Grand Rapids office.\n\nHe said the Grand Rapids office had received a total of 11 reports of tornadoes from storm spotters, emergency managers and the public from late Tuesday afternoon into Tuesday night, but as of 8 a.m. Wednesday, it had not confirmed any tornado touchdowns.\n\nSutton said it could be a couple days before the storm surveys are completed and he stressed that some of the tornado reports could be duplicate reports passed along by people who saw the same storm.\n\n\"It's quite possible those are multiple reports from the same tornado. The actual number of tornadoes may be lower depending on what they find when they're out surveying,\" he said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTuesday's storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nAcross the U.S., the entire week is looking stormy. The Midwest and the South are expected to get the brunt of the bad weather through the rest of the week, including in Indianapolis, Memphis, Nashville, St. Louis and Cincinnati -- cities where more than 21 million people live. It should be clear over the weekend.\n\nOn Monday night, a deadly twister in Oklahoma tore through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall. At least one person was killed and another was missing. Dozens of homes were destroyed.\n\nAerial videos showed homes reduced to piles of rubble and others with roofs torn off. The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town. A 160-acre (65-hectare) wax manufacturing facility in the community also sustained heavy damage.\n\nIt was the second tornado to hit Barnsdall in five weeks -- a twister on April 1 with maximum wind speeds of 90 to 100 mph (145 to 161 kph) damaged homes and blew down trees and power poles.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt the Hampton Inn in nearby Bartlesville, several splintered two-by-fours were driven into the building. Chunks of insulation, twisted metal and other debris were scattered over the lawn, and vehicles in the parking lot were heavily damaged, with blown-out windows.\n\nHotel guest Matthew Macedo said he was ushered into a laundry room to wait out the storm.\n\n\"When the impact occurred, it was incredibly sudden,\" he said.\n\nOklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt, who toured the twister's damage Tuesday, said it was rated by weather researchers as a violent tornado with winds reaching up to 200 mph (322 kph). Stitt said he and legislative leaders have agreed to set aside $45 million in this year's budget to help storm-damaged communities.\n\nAreas in Oklahoma, including Sulphur and Holdenville, are still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.\n\n___\n\nMurphy reported from Oklahoma City. Associated Press journalists around the country contributed to this report, including Rio Yamat, Heather Hollingsworth, Colleen Slevin, Jim Salter, Kathy McCormack, Sarah Brumfield and Beatrice Dupuy.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press' climate and environmental coverage receives financial support from multiple private foundations. (KFOR) - Oklahomans woke up to the first images of the devastation left after an EF4 tornado went through Barnsdall Monday night.\n\nTulsa National Weather Service officials have been surveying the damage and have rated the tornado a preliminary EF4.\n\nGovernor Kevin Stitt posted on his \"X\" account, \"Devastating images coming out of Barnsdall, OK this morning. First responders spent the night executing search and rescue operations. Resources are being directed to the area to aid in recovery. I will travel to Barnsdall later this afternoon. Hold them in your prayers!\"\n\nDamage reported after deadly storms move through Oklahoma\n\nAccording to officials, a large tornado took a damaging hit in and around Barnsdall, and a few miles northwest in Washington County and Bartlesville after the National Weather Service issued a Potentially Dangerous Situation (PDS) Tornado Watch on Monday afternoon.\n\nBarnsdall officials have reported one death after the tornado ripped through the town around 10 p.m. on Monday.\n\nOfficials are also assessing the extensive storm damage reported in the area, as well as in Bartlesville.\n\nU.S. Senator James Lankford on \"X\" posted, \"Cindy and I continue to pray for rain for the western part of the state, but we hope that the storms calm for the rest of this spring. The FREE Red Cross Emergency app puts weather alerts and preparedness info at your fingertips in English and Spanish. Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.\n\nThe storm that hit Barnsdall moved farther northeast, and the National Weather Service reported damage in Bartlesville near the Hampton Inn at U.S. 75 and Tuxedo Road \"likely due to a tornado.\"\n\nThe Osage County Sheriff's Office reported via social media around 10:30 p.m. that \"emergency crews are responding to the Barnsdall area currently. State Highway 11 at State Highway 99 will be closed. Please DO NOT try to go to the area or drive around any barricades.\"\n\nThe Washington County Emergency Management agency reported on social media around 10:30 that it was receiving multiple reports of damage throughout the area. and power lines were down approximately 1 mile south and 2 miles east of South Coffeyville, the National Weather Service reported about 11:45 p.m.\n\nIn Craig County, the Emergency Management Agency The twisters were reported in Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Tennessee and South Dakota.\n\nThe most destructive storm appeared in Barnsdall, Oklahoma, north of Tulsa, where major damage was reported. One person was killed in Barnsdall, according to Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden.\n\nFifteen people were treated for injuries at Ascension St. John Jane Phillips Medical Center in Bartlesville, about 20 miles south of Barnsdall.\n\nIn addition to tornadoes, 4-inch hail, about the size of a softball, was reported in Kansas.\n\nA tornado watch had been issued Tuesday morning for parts of Missouri -- including St. Louis -- and Illinois. The tornado, which struck in the late afternoon, left residents reeling from the widespread damage and destruction.\n\nThe drone footage shows that the tornado carved a path of chaos through Barnsdall, north of Tulsa, demolishing homes, uprooting trees, and sending debris flying. Eyewitnesses described scenes of utter devastation, with buildings reduced to rubble and vehicles tossed aside by the powerful winds.\n\nTulsa TV station KOTV reported that Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden confirmed that one person had died in Barnsdall on Monday. This is the second time Barnsdall has been hit by a tornado in a month.\n\nThe mayor of Barnsdall, Johnny Kelley, told Fox News that an attempt to activate sirens had failed because they malfunctioned after a lightning strike.\n\nHe said: \"In between the 60 seconds or so it takes for the sirens to activate, our siren on the hill took a direct lightning strike and it got the breaker and then our other two sirens, it blew up the AC/DC converters in both of those.\"\n\nThe Oklahoma Department of Emergency Management has asked residents to report damage to their property at damage.ok.gov., which they say helps local and state emergency managers better coordinate response and recovery efforts. The department is coordinating with several Oklahoma agencies and organizations including the Highway Patrol, State Department of Health, National Guard, Department of Transportation, Office of Homeland Security, Department of Agriculture, and Oklahoma American Red Cross.\n\nThe full extent of the destruction is still being assessed, but preliminary reports suggest that hundreds of homes have been damaged or destroyed, leaving many families homeless. Power lines have been downed, roads blocked, and communication networks disrupted, further complicating recovery efforts.\n\nOklahoma State Department of Health reported that a nursing home was damaged and patients evacuated.\n\n\"Please pray for us,\" the Barnsdall Nursing Home wrote on social media.\n\nOklahoma Highway Patrol was assisting with rescues as several roads were closed because Forecasts warn more is to come", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nIn Kansas, some areas were pelted by apple-sized hail 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) in diameter.\n\nThe storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month. Both the Plains and Midwest have been hammered by tornadoes this spring.\n\nOklahoma's State Emergency Operations Center, which coordinates storm response from a bunker near the state Capitol, remains activated from last weekend's deadly storms.\n\nThe Weather Service said more than 3.4 million people, 1,614 schools and 159 hospitals in Oklahoma, portions of southern Kansas and far northern Texas, faced the most severe threat for tornadoes on Monday.\n\nMonte Tucker, a farmer and rancher in the western Oklahoma town of Sweetwater, had spent Monday putting some of his tractors and heavy equipment in barns to protect it from hail. He said he let his neighbors know they could come to his house if the weather becomes dangerous.\n\n\"We built a house 10 years ago, and my stubborn wife put her foot down and made sure we built a safe room,\" Tucker said. This includes the cities of Indianapolis in Indiana, Columbus and Cincinnati in Ohio and Louisville and Lexington in Kentucky.\n\nMeanwhile, tornado watches have been issued for parts of Oklahoma and Arkansas until 5am CT and in parts of Illinois and Missouri until 8am CT, but storms are expected to stretch from Texas to Pennsylvania.\n\nA level two storm warning has been issued for northeastern Arkansas, and cities in Illinois, Tennessee and Michigan, where people could see hail, damaging wind gusts and isolated tornadoes. A level one storm warning is also in place from Texas to Wisconsin, extending east to Pennsylvania, with large hail and damaging winds expected.\n\nAdditional strong to severe storms will be possible on Wednesday evening, according to the National Weather Service, with storms continuing to soak the East from the southern Plains into the mid-Mississippi, Ohio and Tennessee valleys, the Storm Prediction Center forecasts.\n\n\"All severe hazards, including tornadoes, very large hail, and severe/damaging winds should occur. Some of the tornadoes may be strong,\" the prediction center said.\n\nIt comes after one person was killed in a powerful tornado that hit Barnsdall, Oklahoma on Monday night. Several others were also left injured after dozens of homes were damaged and power lines were downed, Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told CNN affiliate KOKI.\n\nMr Virden did not specify how many people were injured, but it is believed at least 30 homes were damaged in the Barnsdall area, according to the state's Department of Emergency Management.\n\nAt least ten possible tornadoes were spotted across the Plains region on Monday, including in South Dakota, Tennessee, Kansas and Iowa.\n\nGiant hail was also reported in Kansas, with utility poles being snapped by the severe weather near McPherson. They said no one had been injured, but that residents had to be relocated because of a gas leak.\n\nOfficials said on Tuesday that emergency crews were responding in the Barnsdall area, and asked people to stay off the roads to allow first responders to reach affected areas.\n\nParts of Oklahoma were reported to have been without power after several power lines were downed.\n\nStorm warnings were still in effect in parts of the state, with a \"squall line\" of damaging thunderstorms expected to stretch from central Iowa to around Oklahoma City.\n\nSeveral tornado watches were still in effect across other parts of the central U.S. early on Tuesday, including parts of Kansas, Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois and Iowa.\n\nThese tornadoes come just a week after several deadly tornadoes ripped through Oklahoma, leaving at least four people dead and injuring roughly 100. We did several rescues of people trapped in debris,\" he said.\n\nThe Oklahoma Highway Patrol said on X that it had established a meeting point in the town for anyone searching for loved ones.\n\nBartlesville, 20 miles to the north-east, was similarly affected. Residents were urged to stay inside and stay off the roads.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement for Osage on Monday. \"A large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly tornado is on the ground,\" it said. {"uri": "2024-05-348238756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "21:20:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T21:20:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T21:14:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.koco.com/article/barnsdall-tornado-oklahoma-ok-missing-man-search/60721869", "title": "Barnsdall community bands together after tornado as search continues for missing man", "body": "An urgent search is underway for one person in northeast Oklahoma after a deadly tornado swept through Barnsdall. Search and rescue teams have been looking into the night and all day Tuesday. The search began for two people, but one of them was found and was taken to a hospital by their family. After searching nearby areas, officials are still looking for Wayne Hogue, a man who went missing after the storms. \"What came through last month was bad, don't get me wrong. But what came through last night was really, really bad. There's no comparison,\" said Johnny Kelley, the mayor of Barnsdall. The mayor said the deadly tornado that swept through the town devastated the small community that's nearly 40 miles north of the Tulsa area. The destruction left teams to pick through debris in a search-and-rescue effort. As of Tuesday afternoon, one person was confirmed dead. \"The Oklahoma Highway Patrol is here to establish a unified command system and also help with that secondary grid search,\" said Preston Cox, with the Oklahoma Highway Patrol. The tornado left damage to homes, cattle and even their largest employer. \"We're going through the debris very thoroughly. All the search and rescue teams are going through it with a fine-tooth comb, because nobody wants to miss anything,\" Kelley said. \"The refinery was hit, and they have suffered a lot of destruction there at the refinery, and it'll take a toll on them, because they'll be shut down at this time, and they'll be shut down for some time to get everything rebuilt.\" >> Download the KOCO 5 appKelley said his faith in the town is strong, and he is hopeful in their road to recovery. \"I believe this town is a strong town, and there's a lot of good people here, and they'll bond together just like they did the first tornado, and we'll build back better,\" Kelley said. We did several rescues of people trapped in debris,\" he said.\n\nThe Oklahoma Highway Patrol said on X that it had established a meeting point in the town for anyone searching for loved ones.\n\nBartlesville, 20 miles to the north-east, was similarly affected. A hotel in the town was severely damaged, as shown in social media posts uploaded by witnesses -- firefighters were called to rescue some people trapped inside.\n\nBartlesville's city's government said there had been significant damage across Bartlesville, with some power lines down, but only minor injuries reported so far. Residents were urged to stay inside and stay off the roads.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement for Osage on Monday. \"A large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly tornado is on the ground,\" it said. The tornado watch was extended until 5 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nOsage Nation Emergency Management and local police said on Facebook it had joined \"numerous agencies for search and rescue through the Osage Nation Reservation.\"\n\n\"Our community is strong and eager to help those in need,\" it said.\n\nAcross Oklahoma, more than 25,000 energy customers were without power as of 5 a.m. local time Tuesday, according to the website PowerOutage.us, while 18,000 were without power in Missouri and almost 10,000 in Arkansas.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the severe weather -- which has affected parts of the country for more than five weeks -- will continue at least into Wednesday as an area of low pressure develops over the Great Lakes.\n\nA tornado also swept through Smithville, Tennessee, bringing down trees and damaging houses, as seen in footage uploaded to social media.\n\nThree people had been confirmed dead in Texas as a result of storms and floods there, Gov. It's the second tornado to hit the area since April 1.\n\n\"It's torn up bad, it's in despair, for sure, as well as our citizens,\" said Kelley. \"The town's took a significant blow here lately. It's not good for sure.\"\n\nKelley said crews are still searching for \"one or two\" missing people. He estimated as many as 40 homes were destroyed and about eight people injured.\n\nKelley said residents of a nursing home were \"distributed to health care facilities\" across the area.\n\nCrystal Maxi's grandparents have lived off Highway 123 in Barnsdall for almost 25 years. She arrived around 8 a.m. to see the home she spent a lot of time in as a child leveled.\n\nNo one in Maxi's family was injured. Her grandmother was home alone and took cover in a storm shelter.\n\nThe National Weather Service says it is still determining the strength of the tornado.\n\nGov. "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/11299974/hotel-destroyed-bartlesville-tornado-weather-warnings-forecast/", "title": "Terrifying moment hotel takes direct hit after fatal tornado hits Oklahoma", "body": "FOOTAGE of the tornado that tore through parts of Oklahoma overnight leaving at least one dead has left viewers in shock.\n\nA clip shared on X, formerly Twitter, captured the moment wind gusts of up to 75 mph hit the Hampton Inn hotel in Bartlesville between 9:30 and 10 pm CT.\n\nFilmed from the doorway of the hotel, the video shows the sheets of rain lashing down as the wind batters the trees and buildings, blowing rain down the street.\n\nThe eerie sound of the tornado alarms continually blaring through the city can be heard in the background of all footage from the storm.\n\nAs the lights go out in the hotel, the group of people filming can be seen running further into the safety of the building away from the open doors and blown-out windows.\n\n\"We're in the middle of it right now,\" one of the men tells the person holding the camera as they call it \"insane\" and \"crazy.\"\n\n\"It's absolutely devastating to see the destructive power of a tornado, especially when it strikes populated areas like a Hampton Inn,\" one viewer said on X.\n\nAnother video showed occupants further inside the hotel who were in the dining area as the lights went out and everything around them started sliding and falling.\n\nFire Departments from Bartlesville, Dewey, and Copan successfully rescued those trapped at the hotel in the early hours of the morning.\n\nIt has been reported that a hotel in Bartlesville lost its roof during the storm, but it has not been confirmed if this was the Hampton Inn.\n\nCity officials confirmed that minor injuries had been reported but no fatalities as of yet.\n\nHowever, Osage County Sheriff Eddie Virdin confirmed in the early hours of the morning that one person in Barnsdall had died as a result of the two-mile-wide twister.\n\nAs the funnel ripped through the adjacent city of Barnsdall, The National Weather Service declared a tornado emergency - its most severe alert.\n\nThere were reports of at least 15 tornadoes including seven in the northern part of the state around 11:45 pm CT.\n\n\"Please pray for us,\" workers at a nursing home in Barnsdall said on social media as the tornado hit the facility before confirming all residents were unharmed.\n\nAs residents react to the destruction, many have started reporting multiple fatalities in Barnsdall, which has not been confirmed by officials.\n\n\"Barnsdall is pretty much destroyed I'm hearing...two fatalities so far,\" one person said in a Facebook post.\n\n\"What an ugly night...Multiple fatalities in Barnsdall, and the nursing home took a direct hit. Incredible devastation!\" another said.\n\n\"Looks like the top half of a Hampton Inn was ripped off in Bartlesville, along with tremendous damage all over town...Lots of flooding and tons of wind damage across this whole area.\"\n\nMultiple injuries were also reported in Virdin as shelters and meeting points have been erected across the affected areas for those with missing loved ones or people in need of shelter.\n\nResidents of Barnsdall were told to go to the Pawhuska High School gymnasium while in Bartlesville, B the Light is open to those who are displaced or impacted by power outages.\n\nEntire towns that the tornado left in its wake are now without electricity, Steven Cobb, a meteorologist for the National Weather Service office in Tulsa told The New York Times.", It's a similar story for two towns in western Iowa.\n\nStrong tornado Monday night: A supercell thunderstorm spawned what appeared to be a strong tornado in northeast Oklahoma Monday night. It plowed through Barnsdall, about 30 miles north-northwest of downtown Tulsa.\n\nVideo and photos Tuesday morning showed the extent of the devastation in the town, where 30 to 40 homes were damaged or destroyed and at least one person lost their life.\n\n(Further beef up your forecast with our detailed, hour-by-hour breakdown for the next 8 days - only available on our Premium Pro experience.)\n\nBarnsdall d\u00e9j\u00e0 vu: Just five weeks ago, an EF1 tornado tore a 2-mile path through the southeast side of Barnsdall, damaging homes and outbuildings. That was one of five tornadoes spawned by a supercell thunderstorm on the evening of April 1, according to the National Weather Service in Tulsa.\n\nIowa towns also hit again: At the same time the tornado was tracking toward Barnsdall, radar confimed another tornado was in progress in western Iowa.\n\nSpecifically, it was near the towns of Minden and Shelby.\n\nIf you've been following our coverage the past few weeks, those towns may sound familiar. Just over two weeks ago, a tornado outbreak struck the Plains, including Nebraska and Iowa. An EF3 tornado tracked through parts of Minden, then west of Shelby on April 26. One house in Minden was detached from its foundation and slid 10 yards.\n\nBarnsdall was fairly lucky before this year: According to data compiled by the NWS-Norman, Oklahoma, office, 108 tornadoes were documented in Osage County, Oklahoma, from 1950 through 2023, an average of one to two per year.\n\nWhile a number of them have been strong - at least F/EF2 rating - previous tornadoes around Barnsdall appear to have been weak, rated either F/EF0 or 1.\n\nMORE ON WEATHER.COM\n\n- How To Prepare For Severe Weather Like A Meteorologist\n\n- How NWS Damage Surveys Estimate A Tornado's Strength\n\n- The Enhanced Fujita Scale: A Tornado Rating System\n\nJonathan Erdman is a senior meteorologist at weather.com and has been covering national and international weather since 1996. {"uri": "8116024077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "17:37:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T17:37:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T17:36:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1320143", "title": "17 tornadoes reported in 7 states across the Plains", "body": "(NEW YORK) -- At least 17 tornadoes were reported in seven states overnight into Tuesday morning, as the tornado threat continues Wednesday for parts of the country.\n\nThe twisters were reported in Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Tennessee and South Dakota.\n\nOne of the hardest-hit areas in the storm was Barnsdall, Oklahoma, north of Tulsa. One person was killed and several injured, according to Barnsdall Mayor Johnny Kelley.\n\nKelley said there was \"significant damage\" to much of the small town, including several homes that were \"completely leveled\" and a nursing home that was destroyed.\n\n\"We need a lot of prayers,\" Kelley told reporters during a press briefing following the tornado -- the second to hit the town in recent weeks.\n\nApproximately 25 people were rescued and one to two people remain unaccounted for following an initial search, Kelley said. Another search effort was underway Tuesday, with access to the town closed while authorities conducted the search.\n\nNOAA's Storm Prediction Center in Norman, Oklahoma, had issued the highest-possible severe weather risk alert for multiple intense, long-track tornadoes Monday afternoon and evening.\n\nThe tornado threat moves into Ohio Valley and parts of the southern Great Lakes Wednesday afternoon and evening. The highest tornado threat will be from St. Louis to Paducah, Kentucky, and Evansville, Indiana, to Nashville, Tennessee.\n\nKentucky Gov. Andy Beshear urged residents to prepare for the severe weather -- including \"potentially significant tornadoes,\" flooding, hail and high winds -- expected to hit much of the state over the next few days.\n\n\"We have been through all of those and we have seen how deadly they can be,\" Beshear said during a press briefing Tuesday. \"So we need everyone to take action now by making a plan to keep We did several rescues of people trapped in debris,\" he said.\n\nThe Oklahoma Highway Patrol said on X that it had established a meeting point in the town for anyone searching for loved ones.\n\nBartlesville, 20 miles to the northeast, was similarly affected. A hotel in the town was severely damaged, as shown in social media posts uploaded by witnesses -- firefighters were called to rescue some people trapped inside.\n\nBartlesville's city's government said there had been significant damage across Bartlesville, with some power lines down, but only minor injuries reported so far. Residents were urged to stay inside and stay off the roads.\n\nThe National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement for Osage on Monday. \"A large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly tornado is on the ground,\" it said. The tornado watch was extended until 5 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nOsage Nation Emergency Management and local police said on Facebook it had joined \"numerous agencies for search and rescue through the Osage Nation Reservation.\"\n\n\"Our community is strong and eager to help those in need,\" it said.\n\nAcross Oklahoma, more than 25,000 energy customers were without power as of 5 a.m. local time Tuesday, according to the website PowerOutage.us, while 18,000 were without power in Missouri and almost 10,000 in Arkansas.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the severe weather -- which has affected parts of the country for more than five weeks -- will continue at least into Wednesday as an area of low pressure develops over the Great Lakes.\n\nA tornado also swept through Smithville, Tennessee, bringing down trees and damaging houses, as seen in footage uploaded to social media.\n\nThree people had been confirmed dead in Texas as a result of storms and floods there, Gov. No deaths have been confirmed and all injuries there are believed to be minor.\n\n-?As the storms marched east early Tuesday, a radar-confirmed tornado with a debris signature struck near the town of Sullivan, Missouri, damaging this bar. {"uri": "8115709785", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "14:06:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T14:06:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:05:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://en-volve.com/2024/05/07/powerful-tornadoes-devastate-small-towns-in-oklahoma-footage/", "title": "Powerful Tornadoes Devastate Small Towns In Oklahoma [FOOTAGE]", "body": "From 100PercentFedUp - READ ORIGINAL\n\nSome media, including videos, may only be available to view at the original.\n\nShare this:\n\nDestructive weather Monday night caused catastrophic damage in parts of Oklahoma.\n\nNortheastern Oklahoma witnessed some of the most significant damage, as storms destroyed homes in the towns of Barnsdall and Bartlesville.\n\nPer FOX Weather:\n\nOne person has died after a devastating tornado destroyed homes and toppled power lines as it moved through a small town northeast of Oklahoma City on Monday evening.\n\nThe National Weather Service (NWS) reports that Barnsdall, a town of about 1,000 people located a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa, was leveled shortly after 10:30 p.m. by a tornado that was initially estimated at EF-3 strength or higher on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.\n\nThe nearby town of Bartlesville also suffered severe damage from the same tornado. Multiple injuries are reported, but the exact number has yet to be confirmed. Damage surveys will continue on Tuesday.\n\nWATCH:\n\n\"So far, four tornadoes have been confirmed and four others were reported during Monday night's storms. Four were in north-central Oklahoma, with the others being in northeastern and eastern Oklahoma,\" KOCO 5 News reports.\n\nKOCO 5 News provided the following damage reports:\n\nBlaine County Emergency Management reports damage to an abandoned hog farm and tank battery, as well as a house struck by lightning. Okeene Emergency Management reports flooded streets, tree damage and downed powerlines. Craig County Emergency Management reports damage to 4-5 homes in Welch and the Welch School old gym. Garfield County Emergency Management reports downed trees and water over the road south of Waukomis, near Bison; and north of Covington. Several vehicles hydroplaned into ditches with no injuries reported. Three barns were destroyed south of Bison. Grove Emergency Management reports minimal tree damage and street flooding. Kingfisher County reports roof damage to at least one home in Lacey, and one barn damaged near Hennessey. Power poles are down near Hennessey. Flash flooding occurred in Kingfisher. Lincoln County Emergency Management reports flooding in Chandler, Tryon and Wellston areas as well as debris in some roadways. Osage County Emergency Management reports tornado damage in Barnsdall area. Oklahoma Highway Patrol reports 30-40 homes damaged in the Barnsdall area. A natural gas leak is also reported. Oklahoma State Department of Health reports a nursing home was damaged and patients are being evacuated. No nursing home patients have injuries requiring hospital care. The Regional Medical Response System is coordinating the evacuation and providing assistance with medical needs. A Natural Gas Leak is reported in Barnsdall and numerous roads are closed due to debris in roadways. Oklahoma Highway Patrol is assisting with rescues. Crews from the numerous jurisdictions are responding to assist with medical transport, traffic and perimeter control, and search and rescue, including: Barnsdall, Blackwell, Cleveland, Fairfax, Mayes County, Nowata County, Owasso, Ponca City, Rogers County, and Oklahoma Task Force 1 Tulsa. A Natural Gas Leak is reported in Barnsdall and numerous roads are closed due to debris in roadways. FirstNet is sending a Cell on Wheels (COW) to assist with cell phone coverage for responders. Wind damage in the Shidler area is also reported. Ottawa County Emergency Management reports trees down northwest of Commerce. Pottawatomie County Emergency Management reports multiple flooded roads due to heavy rain. Washington County/Bartlesville Emergency Management reports damages to residential and commercial structures, including the Hampton Inn and the Medical Park. Five injuries reported. At least 60 homes were damaged or destroyed.\n\nSome homes were flattened and others are without a roof or windows. One of the town's largest employers also has major damage.\n\nSearch and rescue crews saved 25 people Monday night into Tuesday morning.\n\nSusan Love has lived in Barnsdall all her life and said she never wanted to see anything stronger than the April 1 tornado. But she said this second storm did a lot more damage and was terrifying.\n\n\"It sounded like a train went right over the top of us. (My) ears were popping like painfully, just repeatedly. It felt like all of the air came out our cellar. It was a pressurized feeling. None of us have been through anything like that. We didn't really feel that with the first (tornado),\" Love recalled.\n\nLove said even though her town got hit the hardest, she's thankful it wasn't worse. She said they will bounce back.\n\n\"This could have been a lot worse. I mean we did have loss of life and that's horrible. But we all get together and help our neighbors. And Barnsdall will push through it. We always do. That's one good thing about living here. Everybody always comes together,\" Love said.\n\nSchool will not be in session for the rest of week. Many people in the town are displaced due to that significant damage.\n\nThe Barnsdall Nursing Home took a hit, with part of the roof collapsing. That location is at 219 North Virginia.\n\nThe Women's Building at the Fairgrounds in Pawhuska will also be open for anyone who is displaced. {"uri": "2024-05-347945322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:41:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:41:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T14:55:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://tulsaworld.com/news/state-regional/weather/update-fatality-reported-after-barnsdall-tornado/article_a7aba9b6-0c22-11ef-afb3-a3db823603af.html", "title": "Update: Fatality reported after Barnsdall tornado", "body": "Mike Simons\n\nTulsa World Staff Photographer\n\nFollow Mike Simons Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! Your notification has been saved. There was a problem saving your notification.\n\n{{description}}\n\nEmail notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.\n\nSave Manage followed notifications Close Followed notifications Please log in to use this feature Log In Don't have an account? Sign Up Today Mike Simons\n\nThe Osage County town of Barnsdall took a direct hit from a large tornado Monday night, with one fatality confirmed early Tuesday.\n\nMayor Johnny Kelley reported the death during a news conference from Barnsdall.\n\n\"The individual that we lost -- I knew him pretty well,\" Kelley said, adding how difficult it is as mayor to survey the damage affecting so many people he knows in the small town.\n\nFirst responders reportedly were going door to door doing search and rescue at homes that had been damaged or destroyed by the storm. The community of approximately 1,300 people about 40 miles northwest of downtown Tulsa was also hard hit by a tornado about one month earlier, on April 1.\n\nWeather\n\nPhotos: Search through damage underway after storms hit Barnsdall\n\nMike Simons\n\nMonday night's storm moved farther northeast, and the National Weather Service reported damage in Bartlesville near the Hampton Inn at U.S. 75 and Tuxedo Road \"likely due to a tornado.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nGeorge Kaiser lays out plans for his family foundation's future Zink Lake opens this summer. Here's what you need to know 9 Tulsa-area restaurants that are scheduled to open in the coming year Tulsans mourn court clerk staffer slain in 'senseless act' Severe weather expected Monday night | Watch meteorologist Kirsten Lang's forecast Tornado Watch until 11 p.m. for central Oklahoma Update: Fatality reported after Barnsdall tornado The story behind a famous photo during a historic Oklahoma tornado outbreak Chief Wendell Franklin to retire after 27 years at Tulsa Police Department Former OU softball star Jocelyn Alo becomes first woman to sign with Savannah Bananas baseball team OU softball coach Patty Gasso confirms agreement to continue Bedlam in 2025 Oklahoma not alone in states taking millions in losses on cashless tolling Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Tulsa to open new steakhouse concept School leaders question Walters' education agency role in steep declines in national high school rankings New Oklahoma law targets kids' access to porn\n\nThe tornado was confirmed on the ground just west of Skiatook Lake just after 9:15 p.m. and continued to track to the northeast through Barnsdall and the Bartlesville area.\n\nSkiatook's vice mayor early Tuesday confirmed minimal damage in the area after a tornado began forming just north of Ranchland Road about five miles west of the Osage Casino in Skiatook.\n\nThe Washington County Emergency Management agency reported on social media around 10:30 that it was receiving multiple reports of damage throughout the area. It said in a separate post that \"Washington Blvd (highway 75) is blocked both directions north of Frank Phillips and south of Tuxedo due to debris.\"\n\nPower outages continue to affect residents in Washington County; about 3,500 PSO customers are without power as of 10 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | YouTube | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIn Nowata County, damage was reported to homes and power lines were down approximately 1 mile south and 2 miles east of South Coffeyville, the National Weather Service reported about 11:45 p.m.\n\nIn Craig County, the Emergency Management Agency reported that the roof was blown off the old gymnasium in Welch and that debris was around the school.\n\n\"Some forecasters said you are going to see a long-trail tornado greater than an EF-3, and they about got it right,\" Tulsa Area Emergency Management Authority Director Joe Kralicek said early Tuesday.\n\nRadar reportedly picked up debris 15,000 feet in the air as the storms approached Barnsdall, Kralicek said, a clear indication of the power of the tornado.\n\n\"This is still tornado alley,\" he said.\n\nTulsa escaped the worst of the storms, with some strong winds and flash flooding in parts of the city, according to Kralicek, but otherwise no serious impact.\n\nMore information will be posted as it becomes available.\n\nThe Tulsa World is where your story lives.\n\nPhotos: Search through damage underway after storms hit {"uri": "8115879825", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "15:54:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T15:54:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T15:53:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.oann.com/newsroom/1-dead-after-devastating-oklahoma-tornadoes-as-millions-in-the-midwest-face-a-strong-tornado-threat/", "title": "1 Dead After Devastating Oklahoma Tornadoes As millions In The Midwest Face A Strong Tornado Threat", "body": "At least one person has died in Oklahoma as a result of a strong tornado that ripped through small towns, as severe storms moved from the South and into central areas , causing devastation throughout.\n\nOsage County Sheriff Eddie Virden told NBC News that the unidentified person died as a result of a tornado in Barnsdall, a city of close to 1,000 people, which was among some of the storm's worst devastation, on Monday night.\n\nAccording to the National Weather Service (NWS), Barnsdall was hit after 10:30 p.m. by a tornado that was estimated at EF-3 strength or higher on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.\n\n\"It just hit all of a sudden,\" said Joy King, who felt pressure in her ears, which intensified into a loud noise. The storm cellar door she was hiding in then blew open, and debris started to fly everywhere. \"I even had it latched to a bolt in the floor, and it just ripped it off.\"\n\nBartlesville, 20 miles to the northeast of Tulsa, was affected in a similar way. A hotel in the town was severely damaged, as several social media posts began to surface from multiple witnesses, which resulted in firefighters being called in to rescue people trapped inside.\n\nBartlesville's city's government said there had been significant damage across the area, with power lines being hit causing them to go out. Minor injuries have been reported so far and residents were told to stay inside and off the roads.\n\nAdditionally, the National Weather Service issued a rare tornado emergency statement for Osage on Monday. \"A large, extremely dangerous and potentially deadly tornado is on the ground,\" it said. The tornado watch was extended until 5 a.m. Tuesday.\n\nOsage Nation Emergency Management along with local police said on Facebook it had joined \"numerous agencies for search and rescue through the Osage Nation Reservation.\"\n\n\"Our community is strong and eager to help those in need,\" it said.\n\nMeanwhile, the Sooner State saw over 25,000 energy customers were without power as of 5 a.m. local time Tuesday, according to the website PowerOutage.us, with 18,000 without power in Missouri and close to 10,000 in Arkansas.\n\nThe National Weather Service said the heavy weather will continue into Wednesday as an area of low pressure develops over the Great Lakes.\n\nTexas Governor Greg Abbott also said on Monday that three people had been confirmed dead in Texas as a result of the harsh storms.\n\nCurrently, severe thunderstorms are still moving across the Midwest at a rapid pace, with over 29 million people under a severe storm risk, which include areas in Tennessee, Ohio River Valleys, Chicago; Nashville, Tennessee; Toledo, Ohio; and Ann Arbor, Michigan could also see devastating weather.\n\nStay informed! One person died in the community of 1,000, according to KOCO News.\n\nFive others were injured in Bartlesville, a town of 30,000, the ABC affiliate in Oklahoma City reported.\n\nVideo footage aired on local media and social media showed destroyed houses, downed powerlines and trees and debris strewn across roadways throughout the area. Some 16,000 homes and businesses were without power in Oklahoma, according to Poweroutage.us.\n\nStorm spotters reported 17 tornadoes touched down in the Plains region overnight, including eight sightings in Missouri, according to the National Weather Service, which has yet to confirm whether the damage or casualties were caused by tornadoes.\n\nThe dangerous weather was expected to remain on {"uri": "8115960212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:48:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:48:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:48:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://redstate.com/smoosieq/2024/05/07/watch-the-tornadic-devastation-of-barnsdall-oklahoma-drives-home-the-importance-of-weather-awareness-n2173867", "title": "WATCH: The Tornadic Devastation of Barnsdall, Oklahoma, Drives Home the Importance of Weather Awareness", "body": "The opinions expressed by contributors are their own and do not necessarily represent the views of RedState.com.\n\nIt's peak Tornado Season, which means those of us who live in or adjacent to \"Tornado Alley\" have to keep an eye on storm predictions and the radar -- thankfully made easier and more accessible these days by weather and radar apps.\n\nAs someone who follows tornado talk closely, I was aware that the predictions for Monday afternoon and evening were rather bleak in terms of the likelihood that dangerous storms would blow through primarily Oklahoma and Kansas. It was concerning enough that I even took the closing segment of the (political) show I sub-hosted on Monday to discuss that likelihood and the importance of weather awareness.\n\nThis gives an idea of how the outlook appeared as of mid-day on Monday.\n\nAs I alluded to in the segment, once I was home and settled, I parked in front of the computer and began following Tornado Twitter and watching the pertinent live streams. I've referenced Ryan Hall's channel previously. I recently found \"Max Velocity\" and recommend his channel as well.\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nTwisted: A Second Night of Monster Midwest Tornadoes Brings Devastation to Oklahoma\n\nVideo: Incredible Tornadoes Wreak Havoc Across the Heartland\n\nOf course, the storm chasers were out in full force, many of them in Oklahoma, since that appeared to be where the risk was highest. A few storms kicked up through the afternoon and early evening, but nothing of particular note -- so much so that the chatter on the channels began to speculate maybe the threat wouldn't materialize. (And yes, there are some for whom this spells disappointment, even while it's clearly a blessing.)\n\nThat changed around 9:30 pm Central when a monstrous storm kicked up northwest of Tulsa.\n\nSoon came descriptions of a large debris ball lofted high.\n\nA Tornado Emergency was declared.\n\nTornado Emergencies are rare and only issued when 'severe threat to human life and catastrophic damage are imminent or ongoing' for a confirmed tornado.\n\nThe storm ripped through the small town of Barnsdall, Oklahoma, population 1,015, before taking aim at Bartlesville, which has a population of close to 38,000. I'll let the video and images shared on Twitter in the aftermath speak for themselves here:\n\nThese videos taken from the Hampton Inn in Bartlesville show the force of the storm.\n\nWarning: Language\n\nDrone footage taken Tuesday morning demonstrates why that second video shows how not to ride out a storm of this nature.\n\nBut it was tiny Barnsdall that really took the brunt of things. This is utterly heartbreaking.\n\nAmazingly, per local reports, only one fatality has been reported thus far, though there are multiple injuries.\n\nBarnsdall Mayor John Kelley confirmed that a person died after a tornado hit the city in northeastern Oklahoma late Monday night. Information about the victim has not been released.\n\nKelley added that seven or eight injuries also have been reported in Barnsdall, and a firefighter was taken to a hospital with chest pains.\n\nOEM officials said in their weather update that five injuries were reported in the Bartlesville and Washington County area.\n\nMonday's hit comes just a little over a month after an EF-1 tornado struck Barnsdall. The sirens didn't activate in that April storm due to a lightning strike. There are reports the sirens did not go off Monday night either.\n\nWhich highlights how critical it is to be and remain weather-aware -- and not just to rely on the sirens. Thankfully, Barnsdall had some lead time based on the warnings issued and radar confirmation of the storm.\n\nThat heads-up from the National Weather Service in Tulsa likely saved lives. While a huge swath of the town is utterly destroyed, it's a blessing the human casualties weren't worse.\n\nWe're not out of the woods yet, though, folks. Tuesday's and Wednesday's forecasts include enhanced risks again -- Tuesday, more to the east (Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky); Wednesday, a bit to the south (Missouri, Arkansas, Illinois, Kentucky, Tennessee).\n\nSo, consider this a Public Service Announcement from me if you're in or near an area at risk: Stay alert. Have a plan. Have a safe place to shelter if need be (lowest level, most interior room, away from windows). Have your devices charged; have close-toed shoes and a flashlight handy. Use those radar apps. And, if you would, say a prayer for the people impacted by these storms and in the path of the ones to come.", "source": {"uri": "redstate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Redstate"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-05-347439943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "08:49:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T08:49:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T08:47:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5058823823928833, "url": "https://www.koco.com/article/barnsdall-bartlesville-tornado-oklahoma-ok-damage/60713699", "title": "Barnsdall and Bartlesville hit hard after another round of tornadoes hits Oklahoma: What we know", "body": "Damage was reported across Oklahoma as severe storms, bringing tornadoes, large hail and destructive wind moved through the state on Monday night into Tuesday morning. Some of the most significant damage was reported after storms hit Barnsdall and Bartlesville in northeastern Oklahoma.The Oklahoma Department of Emergency Management provided an update on the storms, saying the State Emergency Operations Center remains activated due to the impacts of recent storms. Below is what we know about Monday night's and Tuesday morning's storms. Check back throughout the day for more information. Damage reportsBlaine County Emergency Management reports damage to an abandoned hog farm and tank battery, as well as a house struck by lightning. Okeene Emergency Management reports flooded streets, tree damage and downed powerlines.Craig County Emergency Management reports damage to 4-5 homes in Welch and the Welch School old gym.Garfield County Emergency Management reports downed trees and water over the road south of Waukomis, near Bison; and north of Covington. Several vehicles hydroplaned into ditches with no injuries reported. Three barns were destroyed south of Bison.Kingfisher County reports roof damage to at least one home in Lacey, and one barn damaged near Hennessey. Power poles are down near Hennessey. Flash flooding occurred in Kingfisher.Lincoln County Emergency Management reports flooding in Chandler, Tryon and Wellston areas as well as debris in some roadways.Midwest City Emergency Management reports powerlines and limbs down.Osage County Emergency Management reports tornado damage in Barnsdall area.Oklahoma Highway Patrol reports 30-40 homes damaged in the Barnsdall area. A natural gas leak is also reported. Oklahoma State Department of Health reports a nursing home was damaged and patients are being evacuated in Barnsdall. No nursing home patients have injuries requiring hospital care. The Regional Medical Response System is coordinating the evacuation and providing assistance with medical needs. A Natural Gas Leak is reported in Barnsdall and numerous roads are closed due to debris in roadways. Oklahoma Highway Patrol is assisting with rescues in Barnsdall. Crews from the numerous jurisdictions are responding to assist with medical transport, traffic and perimeter control, and search and rescue, including: Barnsdall, Blackwell, Cleveland, Fairfax, Mayes County, Nowata County, Owasso, Ponca City, Rogers County, and Oklahoma Task Force 1 Tulsa. A Natural Gas Leak is reported in Barnsdall and numerous roads are closed due to debris in roadways. FirstNet is sending a Cell on Wheels (COW) to assist with cell phone coverage for responders. Wind damage in the Shidler area is also reported.Ottawa County Emergency Management reports trees down northwest of Commerce.Washington County Emergency Management reports damage from storms. Damage assessments are ongoing.Weatherford Emergency Management reports damage to a barn and tree damage between Butler and Foss Lake.Oklahoma Department of Emergency Management is asking residents impacted by the storms to report damages to their property at damage.ok.gov. American Red Cross sheltersTwo American Red Cross shelters remain open in Murray and Carter counties following the tornadoes on April 27. Those are located at Crossway First Baptist Church, 2108 W. Broadway Avenue in Sulphur, and Christ Community Church Ardmore, 2620 Mount Washington Road, in Ardmore. Another American Red Cross shelter is on standby to open for Barnsdall residents displaced by the storms. That will be at the Gilbert Field House, located at 948 Cedar Avenue in Barnsdall. Power outagesAs of 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, the Oklahoma Corporation Commission reported 45,227 outages across the state. Below is a list of the outages by county in the areas with more than 100 customers impacted. OG&E reported 25,914 outages. Moore - 11,805 Oklahoma City - 5,231 Choctaw - 1,783 Midwest City - 1,692 Del City - 779 Norman - 703 Waukomis - 470 Paden - 406 Drummond - 393 Carney - 340 Jennings - 326 Agra - 252 Tryon - 226 Nicoma Park - 196 Douglas - 171 Bison - 127 Guthrie - 125 Maramec - 108PSO reported 8,547 outages. Washington - 5,039 Osage - 2,340 Tulsa - 334 Craig - 300 Nowata - 211 Delaware - 193 Grady - 118Electric Cooperatives reported 10,766 outages. CKenergy Electric Cooperative reported 3,857 outages. Caddo - 3,209 Canadian - 404 Custer - 184Oklahoma Electric Cooperative reported 3,267 outages Cleveland - 1,573 Grady - 873 McClain - 812Verdigris Valley Electric Cooperative reported 1,294 outages Osage - 768 Washington - 415Northeast Oklahoma Electric Cooperative reported 1,137 outages Craig - 745 Ottawa - 185 Delaware - 159Central Rural Electric Cooperative reported 844 outages Lincoln - 567 Noble - 166Kay Electric Cooperative reported 162 outagesResidents asked to report damageDial 211Oklahomans seeking non-emergency disaster or health and human service information are asked to contact your local 211. Services are available 24 hours a day by dialing 211. OEM officials ask people to only call 911 for emergencies.\n\nDamage was reported across Oklahoma as severe storms, bringing tornadoes, large hail and destructive wind moved through the state on Monday night into Tuesday morning.\n\nSome of the most significant damage was reported after storms hit Barnsdall and Bartlesville in northeastern Oklahoma.\n\nThe Oklahoma Department of Emergency Management provided an update on the storms, saying the State Emergency Operations Center remains activated due to the impacts of recent storms.\n\nBelow is what we know about Monday night's and Tuesday morning's storms. Check back throughout the day for more information.\n\nOklahoma Department of Emergency Management is asking residents impacted by the storms to report damages to their property at damage.ok.gov.\n\nAmerican Red Cross shelters\n\nTwo American Red Cross shelters remain open in Murray and Carter counties following the tornadoes on April 27. Those are located at Crossway First Baptist Church, 2108 W. Broadway Avenue in Sulphur, and Christ Community Church Ardmore, 2620 Mount Washington Road, in Ardmore.\n\nAnother American Red Cross shelter is on standby to open for Barnsdall residents displaced by the storms. That will be at the Gilbert Field House, located at 948 Cedar Avenue in Barnsdall.\n\nPower outages\n\nAs of 12:30 a.m. Tuesday, the Oklahoma Corporation Commission reported 45,227 outages across the state. Below is a list of the outages by county in the areas with more than 100 customers impacted.\n\nCKenergy Electric Cooperative reported 3,857 outages.\n\nOklahoma Electric Cooperative reported 3,267 outages\n\nVerdigris Valley Electric Cooperative reported 1,294 outages\n\nNortheast Oklahoma Electric Cooperative reported 1,137 outages\n\nCentral Rural Electric Cooperative reported 844 outages\n\nOklahomans seeking non-emergency disaster or health and human service information are asked to contact your local 211. Services are available 24 hours a day by dialing 211.
